Description
The Information Security Policy at Squirro AG establishes a comprehensive approach to safeguarding information across all forms and media, ensuring compliance with regulatory,
legal, and contractual obligations. It applies to all employees, contractors, vendors, and any entity accessing the company's networks. The policy covers the design, development,
maintenance, dissemination, and enforcement of security measures, ensuring data confidentiality, integrity, and availability. It includes procedures for handling intellectual property,
conducting background checks, providing security training, and managing disciplinary actions. The policy also outlines security requirements for cloud computing, emphasizes
compliance with ISO/IEC 27001:2022, and mandates regular review and updates to maintain robust information security standards.

1 Purpose and Scope
1.1 Purpose
The Information Security Policy (further - "the policy") at Squirro AG (further - "the company") has been developed to: establish a general 
approach to information security and the minimization of information misuse, compromise, or loss; document security processes and 
measures; uphold ethical standards and meet the company's regulatory, legal, contractual, and other obligations; control business risk; and 
ensure that the appropriate company image and reputation are presented.
1.2 Scope
This policy applies to:
Information in any form, regardless of the media on which it is stored, as well as any facility, system, or network used to store, process, 
and/or transfer information.
All employees, temporary staff, partners, contractors, vendors, suppliers, and any other person (collectively also referred to as Staff, 
Personnel or End Users) or entity that accesses the company's networks or any other public or private network through the company's 
networks or systems.

All activity while using or accessing the company's information or information processing, storage, or transmission equipment, while on 
the company premises (owned, rented, leased, or borrowed) or remotely.
Information resources that have been entrusted to the company by any entity external to the company (i.e., Customers, Staff, and 
others).
Documents, messages, and other communications created on or communicated via the company systems are considered the 
company's business records and, as such, are subject to review by third parties in relation to audits, litigation, process improvement, and 
compliance.
2 Roles and Responsibilities
  
2.1 Chief Information Officer (CIO)
The Chief Information Officer (CIO) is responsible for the strategic oversight of the company's information technology (IT) initiatives. The 
CIO ensures that IT operations align with the company's business goals and objectives, providing leadership in technology planning and 
resource management. The key responsibilities of the CIO include:
Strategic Oversight of Information Technology: Providing strategic direction and oversight for the company's information technology 
(IT) initiatives, ensuring alignment with business goals and objectives.
IT Governance and Compliance: Establishing IT governance frameworks to ensure compliance with regulatory requirements and 
industry standards. Working closely with the RIS to integrate security policies into IT operations.
Resource Management: Managing the allocation of IT resources, including personnel, budget, and technology investments, to support 
the company's strategic objectives and operational needs.
Innovation and Technology Planning: Leading the identification and implementation of new technologies and innovations to enhance 
business performance and maintain a competitive edge.
Collaboration with CISO and RIS: Working in close collaboration with the CISO and RIS to ensure that information security measures 
are integrated into all IT projects and initiatives. Supporting the implementation of security policies and procedures across IT systems 
and infrastructure.
2.2 Chief Information Security Officer (CISO)
The Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) is responsible for developing and implementing the company's information security strategy. 
The CISO ensures the protection of information assets, manages security risks, and oversees compliance with relevant standards and 
regulations. The key responsibilities of the CISO include:
Information Security Strategy: Developing and implementing a comprehensive information security strategy that aligns with the 
company's business goals and objectives.
Risk Management: Identifying and assessing information security risks, and developing mitigation strategies to manage those risks 
effectively.
Policy Development and Implementation: Creating and maintaining information security policies and procedures, ensuring they are 
up-to-date and effectively implemented.
Incident Response: Leading the incident response team to address and manage information security incidents, ensuring timely and 
effective resolution.
Compliance and Audit: Ensuring compliance with relevant information security standards and regulations, and coordinating internal and 
external audits.
Security Awareness and Training: Developing and delivering security awareness and training programs to educate employees about 
information security best practices and responsibilities.
The following roles and responsibilities are to be developed and subsequently assigned to authorized personnel within the company 
regarding implementation of this document.
Groups and individuals definitions are given according to the Information Security Organization Policy .

2.3 Responsible for Information Security (RIS)
The Responsible for Information Security (RIS) plays a critical role in safeguarding the company's information assets. The RIS ensures 
that the company's information security policies and practices are effective, up-to-date, and compliant with relevant standards. The key 
responsibilities of the RIS include:
Design, Development, Maintenance, Dissemination, and Enforcement of Policies: Overseeing the creation, update, and 
enforcement of information security policies. Distributing policies to relevant stakeholders, ensuring they are understood and accessible, 
and enforcing compliance through regular audits and training.
Ensuring Compliance with ISO/IEC 27001:2022: Implementing and maintaining an information security management system (ISMS) 
that meets ISO/IEC 27001:2022 requirements. Conducting internal audits and coordinating external audits to ensure compliance.
Reporting on Information Security Performance: Regularly assessing and reporting the performance of the information security 
program to top management. Highlighting key risks and recommending actions for improvement.
Maintaining and Enforcing ISP Objectives and Measures: Ensuring the implementation of objectives and measures outlined by the 
Information Security Program (ISP). Coordinating with departments to integrate security measures into business processes and using 
tools like the Skills Matrix to define and enforce security roles and responsibilities.
2.4 End Users  
End Users are responsible for adhering to the company's information security policies and procedures. Their responsibilities include:
Compliance with Policies: Understanding and following all information security policies and procedures established by the company.
Information Protection: Ensuring the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of the information they handle. This includes protecting 
information from unauthorized access, modification, or disclosure.
Access Control: Using unique user credentials and ensuring that they are not shared with others. Logging off or locking their 
workstation when not in use.
Incident Reporting: Promptly reporting any security incidents, potential threats, or suspicious activities to the appropriate personnel.
Security Awareness: Participating in all required security awareness training and staying informed about current security practices and 
threats.
Safe Use of Resources: Using company resources, including hardware, software, and networks, in a secure and responsible manner.
Data Handling: Properly handling, storing, and disposing of sensitive information in accordance with company policies.
2.5 Management  
Management is responsible for implementing and enforcing the company's information security policies within their areas of control. Their 
responsibilities include:
Policy Enforcement: Ensuring that all employees under their supervision comply with the company's information security policies and 
procedures.
Security Leadership: Promoting a culture of security awareness and leading by example in following and enforcing security practices.
Risk Management: Identifying and managing information security risks within their departments or teams, and implementing appropriate 
controls to mitigate those risks.
Incident Management: Responding to and managing security incidents within their areas of responsibility, including coordinating with 
the RIS and CISO.
Training and Awareness: Ensuring that their teams receive necessary security training and are aware of their information security 
responsibilities.
Access Control: Approving and regularly reviewing access permissions for their team members to ensure appropriate access levels.
Resource Allocation: Allocating necessary resources, including time and budget, to support the implementation of information security 
measures.
Performance Monitoring: Monitoring and evaluating the performance of their teams in adhering to information security policies and 
taking corrective actions as needed.

These roles and responsibilities help ensure that both End Users and Management are actively engaged in maintaining and enhancing the 
company's information security posture.
3 Information Security Policy
3.1 Background
This policy is the overarching policy over the rest of the security policies, which make up the company's Information Security Program 
(ISP). The series of security policies includes:
Acceptable Use Policy: Outlines acceptable and unacceptable use of the company's information resources to protect against 
misuse.
Asset Management Policy: Provides guidelines for the management and protection of the company's assets throughout their 
lifecycle.
Backup Policy: Establishes procedures for creating, storing, and restoring backups to ensure data availability and integrity.
Business Continuity Plan and Disaster Recovery Plan: Detail strategies and processes to ensure continued operations and data 
recovery in the event of a disruption or disaster.
Code of Conduct: Sets forth the ethical standards and behavioral expectations for all personnel.
Data Classification Policy, Data Retention Policy, and Data Protection Policy: Define the classification levels of data, 
retention periods, and protection measures to safeguard information.
Encryption Policy and Password Policy: Specify requirements for encryption and password management to secure data and 
systems.
Incident Response Plan : Describes the procedures for identifying, managing, and responding to security incidents.
Physical Security Policy: Establishes measures to protect the company's physical assets and facilities from unauthorized access and 
threats.
Responsible Disclosure Policy: Provides guidelines for reporting and managing vulnerabilities discovered in the company's systems.
Risk Assessment Policy: Outlines the process for identifying, evaluating, and mitigating risks to the company's information assets.
Software Development Life Cycle Policy: Sets standards for secure software development practices to ensure the security of 
software applications.
System Access Control Policy: Defines procedures for granting, managing, and revoking access to the company's systems and 
information.
Vendor Management Policy: Establishes criteria and procedures for assessing and managing the security practices of third-party 
vendors.
Vulnerability Management Policy: Details the process for identifying, assessing, and addressing vulnerabilities in the company's 
systems and applications.
3.2 Information Security Objectives
It is the policy of the company that information, in all its forms - written, spoken, recorded electronically, or printed - will be protected from 
accidental or intentional unauthorized modification, destruction, or disclosure throughout its life-cycle. This protection includes an 
appropriate level of security over the equipment and software used to process, store, and transmit that information. Ultimately, the 
information security goal of the company is to maintain:
Confidentiality: Data and information are protected from unauthorized access.
Integrity: Data is intact, complete, and accurate.
Availability: IT systems are available when needed.
The company's information security objectives, consistent with the company's information security program, are:
To protect information from all internal, external, deliberate, or accidental threats: Implementing robust security measures to guard 
against unauthorized access, data breaches, and other threats that could compromise information security.

To enable secure information sharing: Facilitating the safe exchange of information within the company and with external parties while 
ensuring that data confidentiality and integrity are maintained.
To encourage consistent and professional use of information: Promoting adherence to established policies and guidelines for the 
handling and use of information, ensuring that all personnel follow best practices for information security.
To ensure clarity about roles and responsibilities associated with protecting information: Defining and communicating the specific 
responsibilities of employees, contractors, and other stakeholders in safeguarding information assets.
To ensure business continuity and minimize business damage: Developing and maintaining business continuity and disaster 
recovery plans to minimize the impact of disruptions and ensure that critical operations can continue.
To protect the company from legal liability and the inappropriate use of information: Ensuring compliance with relevant laws, 
regulations, and contractual obligations to mitigate the risk of legal consequences and prevent misuse of information.
3.3 Policy Review
Annual Policy Evaluation: At a minimum, on an annual basis, senior management and key personnel will convene to discuss, evaluate, 
and document the company's information security policy. This process ensures that strategic goals and objectives are continually 
developed and aligned with the company's evolving needs and the latest security trends and threats.
Security Policy Review and Update: At least once a year, all security policies will be thoroughly reviewed, modified, and/or edited as 
necessary to meet current security standards. This review process is critical for ensuring that all policies remain effective and relevant in 
the face of new challenges and technologies. All updated policies will be signed and approved by authorized personnel to formalize their 
implementation.
3.4 Accessibility
Employee Access to Policies: All policies and procedures will be made accessible to employees at all times via the compliance 
automation SaaS, Drata. This platform ensures that employees can review the necessary documentation whenever needed, fostering a 
culture of continuous awareness and compliance with the company's security standards. For employee's convenience, the original 
versions of all Policies and Standard Operating Procedures, as well as other related security-related documents are also 
retained in Confluence Squirro Security space, Documents section.
3.5 Exceptions
Approval of Policy Exceptions: Requests for any exceptions to the policies included within the Information Security Program (ISP) 
must be approved by the company's Executive Management after a thorough review. This process ensures that any deviations from 
standard policies are justified and do not compromise the overall security posture.
Annual Review of Approved Exceptions: Any approved exceptions will be reviewed on an annual basis to determine if they remain 
necessary and appropriate. This review helps to ensure that exceptions are not left in place longer than needed and that they continue to 
align with the company's security objectives.
3.5 Personnel Security
Acknowledgement of Policies: All personnel will be required to acknowledge in writing their understanding of the Information Securi
ty Policy, the Code of Conduct, and other topic-specific policies relevant to their job function during onboarding and annually 
thereafter. New hire onboarding, including this acknowledgement, will be completed within 7 (seven) of hire.
Background Checks: Background checks will be conducted on employment candidates prior to hire for direct company's employees. 
Background checks for temporary personnel and third parties (contractors) will be conducted as deemed necessary, often the 
contracting entity is responsible for executing background checks for their employees. These checks will be conducted using a third-
party service provider (e.g. Checkr) and will comply with relevant laws, regulations, and ethical standards, in proportion to business 
requirements. The HR/People team will retain records of these background checks. 

Employment Evaluation: Management will evaluate candidates for employment through a formal interview process. This process may 
include:
Verification of academic and professional qualifications
Identity verifications
Validation of references
Technical interviews
Other steps deemed applicable based on the job position
This comprehensive approach ensures that all personnel are properly vetted and informed of their security responsibilities, maintaining a 
high standard of integrity and security within the company.
3.6 Training
Management will ensure that employees, contractors, and third-party users:
Role and Responsibility Briefings: Are properly briefed on their information security roles and responsibilities prior to being granted 
access to covered information or information systems.
Security Guidelines: Are provided with guidelines that state security expectations of their role within the organization.
Regular Notifications and Updates: Are regularly notified of security changes and updates, as well as reminded of security 
responsibilities to be undertaken, via annual security awareness training and annual policy acknowledgements.
Motivation and Compliance: Are motivated and comply with the security policies of the organization.
Security Awareness: Achieve a level of awareness on security relevant to their roles and responsibilities within the organization.
Employment Terms Compliance: Conform to the terms and conditions of employment, which includes the organization's information 
security policy and appropriate methods of working.
3.7.1 Onboarding and Ongoing Training
New Hire Training: All new hires are required to complete information security awareness training as part of their new employee 
onboarding process and annually thereafter.
Ongoing Training: Ongoing training will include security and privacy requirements as well as training in the correct use of information 
assets and facilities. Records to evidence completion of training for all personnel will be retained.
Supplemental Training Methods: The periodic security awareness training will be supplemented with multiple methods of 
communicating awareness and educating personnel as deemed necessary by management, such as newsletters, web-based training, 
in-person training, periodic phishing simulations, etc.
3.7.2 Communication
The organization will properly communicate to its workforce and, if appropriate, contractors:
Security Updates and Incidents: Security updates, changes, and incidents, as needed, via email or appropriate Slack channels.
Annual Reminders: Reminders for security responsibilities as part of the annual security awareness training.
3.7.3 Incident Response and Contingency Training
In addition, consistent with assigned roles and responsibilities, incident response and contingency training to personnel will be provided:
Initial Training: Within 90 days of assuming an incident response role or responsibility.
Policy Changes: As required by information system or policy changes.
Annual Training: Annually.
Employees hired before the effective date of this policy are exempt from background checks (see Document Effective Date in the 
bottom of this policy).

3.7.4 Insider Threats Training
The company will provide periodic security awareness training to personnel that will cover how to identify and report insider threats. All 
employees at the company are responsible for reporting potential insider threats promptly through the proper organizational channels.
3.7.5 Cloud Service Customers
The company will develop specific training programs for personnel involved in the use and management of cloud services, including:
Cloud Service Business Managers: Training on standards and procedures for the use of cloud services, ensuring effective 
management and integration.
Administrators and Integrators: Detailed instruction on the technical and security aspects of cloud services, including configuration 
and maintenance.
Users: Guidance on the proper use of cloud services, focusing on security practices and risk management.
The training will address:
Standards and Procedures: Clear guidelines and procedures for the use of cloud services.
Information Security Risks: Identification of security risks related to cloud services and strategies to mitigate them.
System and Network Risks: Awareness of the risks associated with system and network environments when using cloud services.
Legal and Regulatory Considerations: Understanding of the legal and regulatory requirements applicable to cloud services.
This training will also be extended to management and supervisory managers, including those of business units, to ensure the effective 
coordination of information security activities across the organization.
3.7.6 Cloud Service Providers
The company's employees are expected to conduct similar awareness, education, and training programs as those provided to cloud service 
customers. This includes:
Awareness and Education Programs: Regular training on cloud service security and management for company employees.
Contractor Training: Instructing contractors on the appropriate handling of customer data and data derived from cloud services, 
ensuring compliance with company standards.
This data may contain information confidential to a customer or be subject to specific limitations, including regulatory restrictions, on access 
and use by the company. Therefore, it is crucial that all involved parties understand and adhere to these restrictions to maintain data 
security and compliance.
3.8 Intellectual Property Rights
The company takes the handling and safeguarding of intellectual property very seriously. Intellectual property rights include software or 
document copyright, design rights, trademarks, patents, and source code licenses.
To ensure this, the following procedures will be maintained:
Software Acquisition: Software will only be acquired through known and reputable sources to ensure that copyright is not violated.
Asset Inventory: An asset inventory will identify all assets requiring protection of intellectual property rights.
Proof of Ownership: Proof and evidence of ownership of licenses, master disks, manuals, etc., will be maintained.
Inventory Review: Regular review of the asset inventory to ensure only licensed software and products are installed.
Compliance with Terms and Conditions: The company will ensure compliance with terms and conditions for software and information 
obtained from public networks.
3.8.1 Cloud Service Customers
When using cloud services, additional procedures will be in place to identify any licensing requirements specific to cloud deployment. This is 
crucial as installing commercially licensed software in a cloud service may inadvertently breach the terms of the software license. This 

procedure will give particular attention to scenarios where the cloud service features are elastic and scalable, which may result in the 
software being used on more systems or processor cores than permitted by the license terms.
3.8.2 Cloud Service Providers
The company will have an established process for responding to intellectual property rights complaints, ensuring the protection of 
proprietary assets. This process will include:
Complaint Handling: A clear procedure for handling intellectual property rights complaints, ensuring prompt and effective resolution.
Protection of Proprietary Assets: Ensuring that all proprietary assets are adequately protected against unauthorized use or 
infringement.
3.9 Information Security Requirements Analysis & Specifications
The company will identify its information security requirements through various methods, ensuring that the results are documented, 
reviewed by all stakeholders, and integrated into the early stages of projects. This process is essential to maintaining a robust and secure 
information environment.
3.9.1 Methods
Policies and Regulations: Reviewing relevant policies and regulations to ensure compliance and alignment with industry standards.
Threat Modeling: Analyzing potential threats to identify vulnerabilities and develop strategies to mitigate them.
Incident Reviews: Assessing past incidents to understand their causes and prevent future occurrences.
Use of Vulnerability Thresholds: Establishing thresholds for acceptable levels of vulnerability and ensuring that they are not exceeded.
3.9.2 Factors
User Authentication Requirements: Determining the level of confidence required towards the claimed identity of users to derive 
appropriate user authentication requirements.
Access Provisioning and Authorization: Establishing processes for access provisioning and authorization for both business and 
privileged or technical users.
User and Operator Responsibilities: Informing users and operators of their duties and responsibilities regarding information security.
Asset Protection Needs: Identifying the protection needs of assets, especially in terms of availability, confidentiality, and integrity.
Business Processes: Ensuring security requirements are integrated into business processes, such as transaction logging and 
monitoring, and non-repudiation requirements.
Other Security Controls: Implementing additional security controls, such as interfaces to logging and monitoring or data leakage 
detection systems.
By systematically identifying and addressing these requirements, the company ensures that its information security measures are 
comprehensive, effective, and aligned with its business objectives.
3.10 Employment Terms and Conditions
The following terms and conditions of employment at the company are the contractual obligations for employees or contractors to safeguard 
information. They include, but are not limited to:
Confidentiality and Non-Disclosure Agreements (NDAs): Signing a confidentiality or non-disclosure agreement prior to accessing 
confidential information and processing facilities.
Legal Responsibilities and Rights: Understanding and adhering to legal responsibilities and rights, particularly concerning intellectual 
property.
Information Classification and Asset Management: Responsibilities for the classification of information and the management of 
organizational assets associated with information, information processing facilities, and information services handled by an employee or 

contractor.
Handling Information from Third Parties: Responsibilities for handling information received from third parties in accordance with the 
company's policies and standards.
Compliance with Security Policies: Reviewing and agreeing to comply with the security policies of the company.
Duration of Responsibilities: Acknowledging that certain responsibilities, particularly concerning confidentiality and intellectual 
property, extend beyond the end of employment.
Non-Compliance Actions: Understanding the actions to be taken for non-compliance with the terms and conditions, and the company's 
security policies, which may include disciplinary measures.
These terms and conditions ensure that all employees and contractors are fully aware of their responsibilities regarding information security 
and are committed to maintaining the integrity and confidentiality of the company's information assets.
3.11 Preserve Confidentiality
Throughout its lifecycle, all nonpublic information that is processed, transmitted, and/ or stored by Squirro must be protected in a manner 
that is consistent with our contractual and legal requirements and reasonable and appropriate for the level of sensitivity, value, and risk 
associated with Nonpublic information (please see the Data Classification Policy). Information that contains data elements from multiple 
classifications must be protected at the highest level of information represented. For example, a document that contains Nonpublic and 
Public information must be treated as Nonpublic information. Nonpublic information must be secured against disclosure, modification, and 
access by unauthorized individuals. 
3.12 Information Security
Employee are responsible for using Squirro's computer resources properly – especially with regard to information security – and you need to 
be thoroughly familiar with Squirro's Information Security policies and procedures.
3.13 Annual Acknowledgment of the Policies
Once each year, as a condition of a person employment, every employee required to acknowledge that they have received the Code of 
Conduct and understand its rules. New employees will sign an acknowledgment when they start with the company. Basically, annual 
acknowledgment confirms that:
Employee reviewed the Code of Conduct and employee are required to comply with the Code of Conduct;
Employee will comply with the compliance policies and procedures, as well as policies and procedures related to your job 
responsibilities;
Employee will report any questions or concerns about suspected or actual violations of the Code according Code of Conduct | 4. 
Raise a Concern;
To the best of your knowledge, employee haven't acted contrary to the Code of Conduct; and
Employee have reported any potential conflicts of interest to the management.
The information must be:
Secured at rest; and
Secured in transit; and
Securely destroyed in accordance with record retention policies and procedures.
These Steps Can Go a Long Way in Preventing Unauthorized Access:
Never share your login information.
Lock your workstation when you step away.
Log off your workstation when you leave for the day.
Clear your workstation, waste can, printers, and fax machines of sensitive information, such as PII or company-sensitive information.

3.14 Disciplinary Process
The company's discipline policy and procedures are designed to provide a structured corrective action process to improve and prevent a 
recurrence of undesirable employee behavior and performance issues. This process is consistent with the company's cultural values, 
Human Resources (HR) best practices, and employment laws.
The company reserves the right to combine or skip steps depending on the facts of each situation and the nature of the offense. The level of 
disciplinary intervention may vary based on factors such as whether the offense is repeated despite coaching, counseling, or training, the 
employee's work record, and the impact the conduct and performance issues have on the organization.
3.11.1 Step 1: Verbal Warning and Counseling
Description: This initial step creates an opportunity for the immediate supervisor to schedule a meeting with an employee to bring 
attention to an existing performance, conduct, or attendance issue. The supervisor should discuss with the employee the nature of the 
problem or the violation of company policies and procedures. The supervisor is expected to clearly describe expectations and the steps 
the employee must take to improve performance or resolve the problem.
3.11.2 Step 2: Formal Written Warning
Description: If the employee does not promptly correct any performance, conduct, or attendance issues that were identified in Step 1, a 
written warning will become formal documentation of the performance, conduct, or attendance issues and consequences. The employee 
will sign a copy of the document to acknowledge receipt and understanding of the formal warning. During Step 2, the immediate 
supervisor and HR representative will meet with the employee to review any additional incidents or information about the performance, 
conduct, or attendance issues as well as any prior relevant corrective action plans. Management will outline the consequences for the 
employee of his or her continued failure to meet performance or conduct expectations.
Performance Improvement Plan (PIP): A formal performance improvement plan (PIP) requiring the employee's immediate and 
sustained corrective action will be issued after a Step 2 meeting. A warning outlining that the employee may be subject to additional 
discipline up to and including termination if immediate and sustained corrective action is not taken may also be included in the written 
warning.
3.11.3 Step 3: Suspension and Final Written Warning
Description: There may be performance, conduct, or safety incidents so problematic and harmful that the most effective action may be 
the temporary removal of the employee from the workplace. When immediate action is necessary to ensure the safety of the employee 
or others, the immediate supervisor may suspend the employee pending the results of an investigation. Suspensions that are 
recommended as part of the normal progression of this progressive discipline policy and procedure are subject to approval from a next-
level manager and HR.
3.11.4 Step 4: Recommendation for Termination of Employment
Description: The last step in the progressive discipline procedure is a recommendation to terminate employment. Generally, the 
company will try to exercise the progressive nature of this policy by first providing warnings, a final written warning or suspension from 
the workplace before proceeding to a recommendation to terminate employment. However, the company reserves the right to combine 
and skip steps depending on the circumstances of each situation and the nature of the offense. Furthermore, employees may be 
terminated without prior notice or disciplinary action.
Approval Process: Management's recommendation to terminate employment must be approved by HR and the supervisor's immediate 
manager. Final approval may be required from the CEO.
3.11.5 Performance and Conduct Issues Not Subject to Progressive Discipline
Behavior that is illegal is not subject to progressive discipline, and such behavior may be reported to local law enforcement authorities. 
Theft, substance abuse, intoxication, fighting, and other acts of violence at work are grounds for immediate termination.

3.11.6 Enforcement
Authority: The company's management, under the explicit authority granted by the company CEO, retains the authority and 
responsibility to monitor and enforce compliance with this policy and other policies, standards, procedures, and guidelines. Monitoring 
activities may be conducted on an ongoing basis or on a random basis whenever deemed necessary by management and may require 
investigating the use of the company's information resources. The company reserves the right to review any and all communications and 
activities without notice.
Precautions: The company will take appropriate precautions to ensure that monitoring activities are limited to the extent necessary to 
determine whether the communications or activities are in violation of company policies, standards, procedures, and guidelines or in 
accordance with normal business processing performance or quality activities.
Violation Consequences: Violation of the controls established in this policy is prohibited and will be appropriately addressed. 
Disciplinary actions for violations may include verbal and/or written warnings, suspension, termination, and/or other legal remedies and 
will be consistent with our published HR standards and practices.
3.12 Cloud Computing
3.12.1 Cloud Service Customers
The company will take the following into account for information security in cloud computing:
Access and Management: Information stored in its cloud computing environment may be accessed and managed by cloud service 
providers.
Asset Maintenance: Assets, such as application programs, could be maintained within the cloud computing environment.
Multi-Tenant Platforms: Processes may run on multi-tenant, virtualized cloud service platforms.
User Context: Specific context of cloud service users and the circumstances surrounding the usage of the cloud service.
Privileged Access: Administrators who have privileged access to the cloud service.
Geographical Considerations: Geographical locations of the cloud service provider's organization and where customer data might be 
stored, even temporarily.
3.12.2 Cloud Service Providers
The company will address the provision and use of its cloud services, taking the following into account:
Baseline Security Requirements: Baseline information security requirements during the design and implementation of cloud services.
Insider Risk Mitigation: Mitigation of risks associated with authorized insiders.
Customer Isolation: Multi-tenancy and cloud service customer isolation, including robust virtualization measures.
Access Controls: Access controls for staff accessing its cloud service customer assets, including strong authentication mechanisms.
Change Management Communication: Effective communication channels with its cloud service customers during change 
management processes.
Virtualization Security: Deployment of robust virtualization security measures.
Data Protection: Access control for the protection of cloud service customer data.
Account Lifecycle Management: Lifecycle management of cloud service customer accounts.
Incident Communication: Communication of security breaches to cloud service customers and providing guidelines and support for 
investigations and forensics to ensure effective incident response and remediation.

policy ensures that all changes, whether planned or unplanned, are thoroughly documented, tested, and approved to minimize risks, system outages, and security vulnerabilities. It

1 Purpose and Scope
1.1 Purpose
The Change Management Policy (further - the policy) defines the processes for managing changes to systems, applications, and 
infrastructure at Squirro AG (further - the company). The policy establishes a framework for introducing, testing, and approving changes in 
a controlled and secure manner, minimizing unplanned outages and unforeseen system issues. The policy applies to all changes related to 
IT systems and services, ensuring proper planning, risk assessment, and documentation for each change to avoid operational disruptions.
1.2 Scope
Applies to all company personnel, including employees, contractors, and third-party service providers responsible for managing or 
implementing changes to the company's IT infrastructure and systems.
Company assets: Covers all systems, applications, networks, data centers, cloud platforms (AWS and Azure), databases, computing 
hardware, and other IT resources.
Business processes: Encompasses all business-critical systems and services that are affected by IT and infrastructure changes, 
including software development, SaaS operations, and support systems.
2 Roles and Responsibilities
2.1 Chief Information Officer (CIO)
The CIO is responsible for ensuring that all IT changes are aligned with the company's business and security objectives and that these 
changes are implemented according to the established procedures.
Approve system changes: Reviews and approves all changes to production systems, network devices, and firewalls to ensure 
compliance with business and security requirements.
Oversee implementation: Ensures that all changes to production environments are implemented by authorized personnel only, 
following approved procedures.
Monitor system health: Ensures that changes do not negatively impact system performance or security, and oversees corrective 
actions if necessary.
The CIO ensures that all changes in the company's IT infrastructure support the strategic goals and are executed securely and efficiently.
2.2 Chief Information Security Officer (CISO)
The CISO is responsible for overseeing the security impact of all changes and ensuring that security controls are maintained throughout the 
change management process.
The following roles and responsibilities are to be developed and subsequently assigned to authorized personnel within the company 
regarding implementation of this document.
Groups and individuals definitions are given according to the Information Security Organization Policy .

Security impact assessment: Ensures that security assessments are conducted for each change to evaluate its potential impact on the 
overall security of the system.
Review security controls: Verifies that changes do not compromise security controls or introduce vulnerabilities into the system.
Coordinate with other teams: Works closely with the DevOps and engineering teams to ensure that security is integrated into all 
stages of the change process.
The CISO plays a critical role in maintaining the security posture of the company by managing and overseeing the security implications of 
any system changes.
2.3 Responsible for Information Security (RIS)
The Responsible for Information Security (RIS) is tasked with the day-to-day management of security controls during the implementation of 
changes, ensuring compliance with security policies.
Implement security controls: Ensures that all necessary security controls are applied during the change process, in line with company 
policies and compliance requirements.
Compliance monitoring: Monitors the change process to verify that it remains compliant with internal security standards and external 
regulatory requirements.
Document security measures: Documents all security actions taken during the change process, including impact assessments, testing, 
and mitigation actions.
The RIS ensures that security controls are enforced and compliance is maintained during the entire change lifecycle.
2.4 Change Requestor
The Change Requestor is responsible for initiating a change by submitting a formal change request that includes the necessary details, 
impact analysis, and supporting documentation.
Submit change requests: Completes and submits a change request form with detailed descriptions of the proposed changes, including 
the business need, expected outcomes, and risk analysis.
Provide documentation: Ensures that all required documentation, including technical specifications and security assessments, are 
attached to the change request.
Coordinate with stakeholders: Works with relevant stakeholders to ensure that the proposed change aligns with business and 
technical requirements.
The Change Requestor plays a vital role in providing the necessary information to evaluate and implement the proposed changes.
2.5 Change Approver
The Change Approver is responsible for reviewing and approving or rejecting change requests based on the documentation and risk 
assessment provided.
Review change proposals: Evaluates the proposed change, including its business impact, security considerations, and resource 
requirements, before deciding on approval or rejection.
Ensure completeness: Confirms that all required documentation, testing, and risk assessments have been completed before approving 
a change.
Authorize implementation: Grants final authorization for changes to be implemented in production environments after ensuring that all 
procedures have been followed.
The Change Approver ensures that only well-documented and secure changes are allowed into production environments.

2.6 DevOps Team
The DevOps Team is responsible for the technical implementation of approved changes, ensuring that they are properly tested and 
deployed in a manner that minimizes risk and downtime.
Implement changes: Executes approved changes in the production environment according to established procedures and schedules, 
ensuring minimal disruption to business operations.
Testing and validation: Performs extensive testing in pre-production environments to ensure that changes do not negatively impact 
system performance or security.
Monitor post-deployment: Monitors the system after changes are implemented to identify any issues and quickly address any failures 
or performance impacts.
The DevOps Team is essential in ensuring that changes are implemented smoothly, with appropriate testing and validation.
2.7 Quality Assurance (QA) Team
The QA Team is responsible for ensuring that changes meet the required quality standards and do not negatively impact system 
functionality or performance.
Test changes: Conducts comprehensive testing of all proposed changes in a controlled environment before they are deployed to 
production.
Verify functionality: Ensures that the changes meet business requirements and perform as expected without introducing bugs or 
system failures.
Report findings: Provides detailed reports on testing outcomes, including any detected issues or risks, to the Change Approver and 
DevOps Team.
The QA Team ensures that all changes are thoroughly tested and validated to prevent issues in production environments.
3 Policy
3.1 Change Management Requirements
The Change Management Policy outlines the procedures required to manage changes across company in a planned and predictable 
manner, minimizing unplanned outages and unforeseen issues. The aim is to implement IT-supported business processes while reducing 
risks and negative impacts on operations.
Documentation of Changes: All changes to system components (operating systems, hardware, networks, applications, data centers) 
must be fully documented, including a detailed description of the change and its impact.
Security Impact: Each change must include a documented analysis of its security impact.
Testing of Changes: Testing must be performed before deployment to verify that the change will not adversely impact system security 
or performance.
Formal Approval: Formal approval is required before any change can be implemented. This approval must be documented.
Separation of Environments: Pre-production environments must be separated from production environments. Access controls must be 
enforced to ensure the separation is maintained.
Rollback Strategy: A rollback strategy must be in place before any change is deployed to ensure a return to a secure state in the event 
of failure.
By following these procedures, Squirro ensures that all changes are managed securely, reducing risks to business continuity and 
operational performance.

3.2 Organizational Change Control Procedures
Organizational change control procedures ensure that changes affecting infrastructure, code, networking, and hardware are properly 
managed.
Change Documentation: Changes to all system components must be documented, including a description of the change.
Security Assessment: Each change must include a documented assessment of its impact on security controls and integrity.
Testing Procedures: All changes must undergo rigorous testing to ensure that security and system performance are not compromised.
Failure Procedures: Procedures for addressing failures during a change, including how to return to a secure state, must be documented 
and approved.
Controls and Integrity Reviews: Before a change is implemented, existing controls and integrity procedures must be reviewed to 
confirm they are not affected.
Vendor Software Modifications: Modifications to vendor-supplied software must be evaluated, including risks to built-in controls, 
vendor consent, and compatibility with other systems.
Technical Review: A technical review must be conducted after changes to operating platforms, including a review of application control 
and integrity.
These procedures ensure that organizational changes are thoroughly planned, tested, and documented to maintain security and system 
integrity.
3.3 Software Development and Application Changes
Changes to software and applications must be managed with a focus on security, usability, and operational performance.
Extensive Testing: All software changes, including updates to operating systems and applications, must undergo extensive testing. 
Testing should cover usability, security, and effects on other systems.
Pre-production Testing: All tests must be conducted in pre-production environments, and corresponding program source libraries must 
be updated.
Authorized Updates: Only trained administrators, with management authorization, are permitted to update operational software, 
applications, and program libraries.
Configuration Control System: A configuration control system will manage all implemented software and related system 
documentation.
Retain Previous Versions: Previous versions of software must be retained as a contingency measure and archived for future reference, 
with relevant information, parameters, and configurations.
These procedures ensure that software development changes are thoroughly tested, authorized, and documented, reducing the risk of 
negative impacts on the operational environment.
3.4 Vendor-Supplied Software and Services
Changes involving vendor-supplied software and services require special attention to ensure compatibility, security, and long-term 
maintainability.
Vendor consent and evaluation: Any modifications to vendor-supplied software must be thoroughly evaluated. This includes obtaining 
consent from the vendor and assessing the risk of compromising built-in controls and integrity processes.
Risk of modification: If modifications to vendor software are necessary, the potential impact on security, functionality, and compatibility 
with existing systems must be carefully analyzed.
Vendor updates: Whenever possible, the company should rely on vendor-provided standard updates to avoid assuming the 
responsibility of maintaining custom modifications. Vendor-supplied changes should be treated as part of the overall change 
management process.
By carefully managing vendor-supplied software and services, the company can ensure that security and compatibility are maintained 
without unnecessary customization that may lead to future support challenges.

3.5 Planned Changes
Planned changes must be managed through a structured process that ensures alignment with business objectives and minimal impact on 
operations.
Plan implementation: For each planned change, a detailed implementation plan must be created. The plan should outline the tasks, 
responsibilities, deadlines, and resources required to complete the change.
Assign roles and deadlines: Clearly assign roles and responsibilities to team members involved in the change, ensuring that all 
deadlines are met.
Monitor execution: Monitor the implementation of changes to confirm that they are executed according to the plan, minimizing 
disruption to business processes and ensuring successful outcomes.
Planned changes should be executed in a controlled, predictable manner to ensure that they align with business goals while maintaining 
system stability.
3.6 Unplanned Changes and Emergency Changes
Unplanned or emergency changes must follow an expedited process while maintaining a focus on risk mitigation and system stability.
Review unplanned changes: Any unintended changes must be reviewed for their consequences and potential for adverse effects. 
Immediate corrective actions should be planned and implemented as necessary.
Emergency changes: In cases where critical vulnerabilities are discovered, emergency changes may be required. Such changes can 
bypass normal procedures to address the immediate threat, but they must still be documented, tested as thoroughly as possible, and 
formally reviewed afterward.
Evaluate after action: After any emergency change, a post-implementation review must be conducted to assess its effectiveness and 
any potential side effects or risks introduced during the process.
These procedures ensure that unplanned and emergency changes are handled swiftly but securely, preventing any unnecessary risks while 
restoring normal operations.
3.7 Configuration Management Requirements
Configuration management ensures that production systems and network changes are tracked, documented, and controlled to maintain 
operational security and integrity.
Standardization and Automation: Tools such as Terraform and Ansible will be used to standardize and automate configuration 
management processes.
Approval of Deployments: No system will be deployed without approval from the CIO. All changes to production systems, network 
devices, and firewalls must be approved by the CIO to ensure compliance with business and security requirements.
Testing Changes: All changes to production systems must be thoroughly tested before implementation to ensure they function as 
expected without introducing risks.
Up-to-date Inventory: A system for generating an up-to-date inventory of all systems and related products and services must be 
maintained, including corresponding architecture diagrams.
Separation of Frontend and Backend: All frontend functionality (e.g., developer dashboards) must be separated from backend 
systems (e.g., databases and app servers), which are deployed on separate servers or containers.
Review of Code: All committed code must be reviewed using pull requests to ensure code quality and proactively detect security issues 
during development.
Staging Environments: Development and staging environments must mirror production to ensure proper functionality before changes 
are moved into production.
Configuration management ensures that all system changes are controlled, tested, and documented to maintain system integrity and 
security.

3.8 Change Security Measures
All changes must comply with the security standards defined by company to ensure system protection and operational integrity.
Branch Protection Rules: GitHub branch protection rules must be enforced to ensure only approved changes reach production.
Security Review: Significant changes must be reviewed and approved by the security team.
Deployment of Changes: Changes must only be deployed to production by authorized personnel with elevated privileges.
Post-Deployment Testing: Post-deployment QA testing must be conducted to ensure that changes are functioning as intended and do 
not introduce new security vulnerabilities.
These measures ensure that all changes to company's systems are implemented securely and effectively, reducing the risk of security 
breaches.

1 Purpose and Scope
1.1 Purpose
The Data Classification Policy (further - the policy) defines guidelines and procedures for labeling and handling information at Squirro AG 
(further - the company). Additionally, the policy establishes a framework for protecting sensitive and confidential information to ensure data 
security and compliance with legal and regulatory requirements for all employees, contractors, and third-party vendors who manage 
company IT resources.
1.2 Scope
This policy applies to all information owned, managed, controlled, or maintained by the company. It covers information received, stored, 
processed, or transmitted via any means, including electronic, hardcopy, and any other form of information regardless of the media on which 
it resides. The policy applies to all company personnel, assets, and information systems.
2 Roles and Responsibilities
2.1 Chief Information Officer (CIO)
The Chief Information Officer (CIO) is responsible for the strategic oversight and approval of the Data Classification Policy. 
Responsibilities include:
Policy Approval: Review and approve the Data Classification Policy and any subsequent revisions.
Resource Allocation: Allocate resources to ensure effective implementation and maintenance of the data classification scheme.
2.2 Chief Information Security Officer (CISO)
The Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) is responsible for the development, implementation, and enforcement of the Data 
Classification Policy. Responsibilities include:
Authorization Management: Grant explicit authorization for access to Restricted and Confidential data.
Policy Enforcement: Ensure strict adherence to data classification and handling procedures across the organization.
The following roles and responsibilities are to be developed and subsequently assigned to authorized personnel within the company 
regarding implementation of this document.
Groups and individuals definitions are given according to the Information Security Organization Policy .

Incident Management: Oversee the response and handling of security incidents related to data classification breaches.
2.3 Responsible for Information Security (RIS)
The Responsible for Information Security (RIS) is responsible for monitoring and assessing risks related to data classification. 
Responsibilities include:
Risk Assessment: Conduct regular risk assessments focused on data classification and handling practices.
Compliance Monitoring: Continuously monitor compliance with the Data Classification Policy and report any non-compliance.
Training and Awareness: Develop and deliver training programs specific to data classification and handling guidelines.
2.4 Information Owners
Information Owners are responsible for the accurate classification and protection of their assigned assets. Responsibilities include:
Data Classification: Accurately classify data according to its sensitivity and business impact.
Data Labelling: The owner of information is responsible for the correct labeling according to the classification.
Protection Measures: Implement and maintain appropriate security controls based on the data classification.
Review Access Controls: Regularly review and update access permissions to ensure compliance with data classification requirements.
2.5 System Administrators
The System Administrators are responsible for the technical implementation of the Data Classification Policy. Responsibilities include:
Data Sanitization: Ensure that data is securely wiped from assets before disposal or repurposing, based on its classification.
Access Control Implementation: Apply and manage access controls in accordance with data classification levels.
Technical Configuration: Implement baseline security configurations tailored to the classification of the data.
2.6 End Users
End Users are responsible for adhering to the Data Classification Policy. Responsibilities include:
Adherence to Classification Guidelines: Handle data according to its classification, following prescribed guidelines.
Reporting Incidents: Report any breaches or mishandling of data classification to the IT department immediately.
Labeling and Handling: Properly label and handle data as per the classification guidelines to prevent unauthorized access or exposure.
3 Policy
3.1 General Approach
3.1.1 Definitions
The following definitions provide clarity on the types of data covered under this policy and the levels of sensitivity assigned to each category. 
These definitions are essential for understanding the data classification scheme and the corresponding handling requirements.
Confidential/Restricted Data: Generalized terms that typically represent data classified as Sensitive or Private, according to the data 
classification scheme defined in this policy. This data requires the highest level of protection due to its potential impact on the company 
and its customers if disclosed, altered, or destroyed without authorization.
Internal Data: All data owned or licensed by the company. This data is intended for use within the organization and must be protected 
from unauthorized access, but it does not carry the same level of risk as Confidential/Restricted Data.
Public Information: Any information that is available within the public domain. This data has no existing local, national, or international 
legal restrictions on access or usage and poses minimal risk to the company if disclosed or altered.

These definitions ensure a common understanding of data types and their respective sensitivity levels, which is crucial for implementing 
appropriate security measures and maintaining compliance with legal and regulatory requirements.
3.1.2 Working Instructions
This working instruction is based on the guideline on the organization's assets and the classification scheme described therein.
Classification Specification: The owner (editor) of the information should specify appropriate classification at the time of its creation.
Labeling Responsibility: The author is responsible for the correct labeling of information.
Periodic Review: Where applicable, the owner should check periodically whether the information is still needed, and the classification is 
still justified.
Adoption of Existing Classifications: If an item of information has already been classified by another entity or a specific classification 
is required contractually, that classification must be adopted.
Printed Information Marking: Printed classified information shall be marked accordingly. The classification note "internal use" or 
"confidential" shall be placed on the title page and/or in the footer of the document.
Electronic Information Tagging: Electronic information and data should be tagged with the available metadata.
Device Labeling: In order to keep the administrative effort within manageable limits, the devices carrying data are not labeled. 
Employees are instructed to treat such devices and mobile devices as if they contained classified information.
Access Control: Access to information categorized as "confidential" is given on a "need-to-know" basis, i.e., an individual only receives 
access to such information to the extent necessary for the performance of his or her work. Information categorized as "internal use" 
should be available to employees by default.
Privileged Users: Classified information is only made available to privileged users. In the case of electronically stored information, 
appropriate authorizations must be assigned.
Security of Devices: Devices carrying data and devices on which classified information is stored shall be kept securely locked or 
password protected (e.g., employee laptops should not be locked, but should be password protected).
Data Deletion: If classified information on data carriers and devices is to be deleted, it should be done in line Asset Management Poli
cy | 3.13 Disposal of Media and Devices and lead to the permanent destruction of such information.
Default Classification: Documents without a label should by default be treated as "Internal Use" unless they are marketing or sales 
materials or materials intended to be available publicly or for selected external parties (which should be verified with the document 
owner).
These generic requirements ensure that information is classified, labeled, reviewed, and protected appropriately, maintaining the security 
and integrity of the company's data throughout its lifecycle.
3.2 Data Classification Scheme
Data classification, in the context of information security, is the classification of data based on its level of sensitivity and the impact to the 
company should that data be disclosed, altered, or destroyed without authorization. The classification of data helps determine what baseline 
security controls are appropriate for safeguarding that data. All data should be classified into one of the following classifications:
3.2.1 Confidential/Restricted Data
Data should be classified as Confidential/Restricted when the unauthorized disclosure, alteration, or destruction of that data could cause a 
serious or significant level of risk to the company or its customers. Examples of sensitive data include data protected by state or federal 
privacy regulations (e.g., PHI & PII) and data protected by confidentiality agreements. The highest level of security controls should be 
applied to Confidential/Restricted Data:
Access Restrictions: Disclosure or access to Confidential/Restricted data is limited to specific use by individuals with a legitimate need-
to-know. Explicit authorization by the CISO is required for access due to legal, contractual, privacy, or other constraints.
Protection Measures: Must be protected to prevent loss, theft, unauthorized access, and/or unauthorized disclosure.
Data Destruction: Must be destroyed when no longer needed. Destruction must be in accordance with company policies and 
procedures.

Incident Response: Will require specific methodologies, procedures, and reporting requirements for the response and handling of 
incidents.
3.2.2 Internal Use Data
Data should be classified as Internal Use when the unauthorized disclosure, alteration, or destruction of that data could result in a moderate 
level of risk to the company or its customers. This includes proprietary, ethical, or privacy considerations. Data must be protected from 
unauthorized access, modification, transmission, storage, or other use. This applies even though there may not be a civil statute requiring 
this protection. Internal Use Data is restricted to personnel who have a legitimate reason to access it. By default, all data that is not explicitly 
classified as Confidential/Restricted or Public data should be treated as Internal Use data. A reasonable level of security controls should be 
applied to Internal Use Data.
3.2.3 Public Data
Data should be classified as Public when the unauthorized disclosure, alteration, or destruction of that data would result in little or no risk to 
the company and its customers. It is further defined as information with no existing local, national, or international legal restrictions on 
access or usage. While little or no controls are required to protect the confidentiality of Public data, some level of control is required to 
prevent unauthorized alteration or destruction of Public Data.
3.2.4 De-identified Data
The company will de-identify data as a tool to remove personal information from data that it collects, uses, archives, and shares with other 
organizations. The de-identification process will allow the removal of direct identifiers, including all unique identifying numbers, 
characteristics, or codes. If a data set contains any amount or type of personal information, it will not be considered de-identified.
This data classification scheme ensures that all data handled by the company is appropriately classified based on its sensitivity and 
potential impact. By assigning one of the defined classifications, the company can implement suitable security controls to protect the data, 
thereby maintaining data confidentiality, integrity, and availability.
3.3 Assessing Classification Level and Labeling
The goal of information security, as stated in the Information Security Policy, is to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of 
Corporate and Customer Data. Data classification reflects the level of impact to the company if confidentiality, integrity, or availability is 
compromised.

1 Purpose and Scope
1.1 Purpose
The Data Classification Policy (further - the policy) defines guidelines and procedures for labeling and handling information at Squirro AG 
(further - the company). Additionally, the policy establishes a framework for protecting sensitive and confidential information to ensure data 
security and compliance with legal and regulatory requirements for all employees, contractors, and third-party vendors who manage 
company IT resources.
1.2 Scope
This policy applies to all information owned, managed, controlled, or maintained by the company. It covers information received, stored, 
processed, or transmitted via any means, including electronic, hardcopy, and any other form of information regardless of the media on which 
it resides. The policy applies to all company personnel, assets, and information systems.
2 Roles and Responsibilities
2.1 Chief Information Officer (CIO)
The Chief Information Officer (CIO) is responsible for the strategic oversight and approval of the Data Classification Policy. 
Responsibilities include:
Policy Approval: Review and approve the Data Classification Policy and any subsequent revisions.
Resource Allocation: Allocate resources to ensure effective implementation and maintenance of the data classification scheme.
2.2 Chief Information Security Officer (CISO)
The Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) is responsible for the development, implementation, and enforcement of the Data 
Classification Policy. Responsibilities include:
Authorization Management: Grant explicit authorization for access to Restricted and Confidential data.
Policy Enforcement: Ensure strict adherence to data classification and handling procedures across the organization.
The following roles and responsibilities are to be developed and subsequently assigned to authorized personnel within the company 
regarding implementation of this document.
Groups and individuals definitions are given according to the Information Security Organization Policy .

Incident Management: Oversee the response and handling of security incidents related to data classification breaches.
2.3 Responsible for Information Security (RIS)
The Responsible for Information Security (RIS) is responsible for monitoring and assessing risks related to data classification. 
Responsibilities include:
Risk Assessment: Conduct regular risk assessments focused on data classification and handling practices.
Compliance Monitoring: Continuously monitor compliance with the Data Classification Policy and report any non-compliance.
Training and Awareness: Develop and deliver training programs specific to data classification and handling guidelines.
2.4 Information Owners
Information Owners are responsible for the accurate classification and protection of their assigned assets. Responsibilities include:
Data Classification: Accurately classify data according to its sensitivity and business impact.
Data Labelling: The owner of information is responsible for the correct labeling according to the classification.
Protection Measures: Implement and maintain appropriate security controls based on the data classification.
Review Access Controls: Regularly review and update access permissions to ensure compliance with data classification requirements.
2.5 System Administrators
The System Administrators are responsible for the technical implementation of the Data Classification Policy. Responsibilities include:
Data Sanitization: Ensure that data is securely wiped from assets before disposal or repurposing, based on its classification.
Access Control Implementation: Apply and manage access controls in accordance with data classification levels.
Technical Configuration: Implement baseline security configurations tailored to the classification of the data.
2.6 End Users
End Users are responsible for adhering to the Data Classification Policy. Responsibilities include:
Adherence to Classification Guidelines: Handle data according to its classification, following prescribed guidelines.
Reporting Incidents: Report any breaches or mishandling of data classification to the IT department immediately.
Labeling and Handling: Properly label and handle data as per the classification guidelines to prevent unauthorized access or exposure.
3 Policy
3.1 General Approach
3.1.1 Definitions
The following definitions provide clarity on the types of data covered under this policy and the levels of sensitivity assigned to each category. 
These definitions are essential for understanding the data classification scheme and the corresponding handling requirements.
Confidential/Restricted Data: Generalized terms that typically represent data classified as Sensitive or Private, according to the data 
classification scheme defined in this policy. This data requires the highest level of protection due to its potential impact on the company 
and its customers if disclosed, altered, or destroyed without authorization.
Internal Data: All data owned or licensed by the company. This data is intended for use within the organization and must be protected 
from unauthorized access, but it does not carry the same level of risk as Confidential/Restricted Data.
Public Information: Any information that is available within the public domain. This data has no existing local, national, or international 
legal restrictions on access or usage and poses minimal risk to the company if disclosed or altered.

These definitions ensure a common understanding of data types and their respective sensitivity levels, which is crucial for implementing 
appropriate security measures and maintaining compliance with legal and regulatory requirements.
3.1.2 Working Instructions
This working instruction is based on the guideline on the organization's assets and the classification scheme described therein.
Classification Specification: The owner (editor) of the information should specify appropriate classification at the time of its creation.
Labeling Responsibility: The author is responsible for the correct labeling of information.
Periodic Review: Where applicable, the owner should check periodically whether the information is still needed, and the classification is 
still justified.
Adoption of Existing Classifications: If an item of information has already been classified by another entity or a specific classification 
is required contractually, that classification must be adopted.
Printed Information Marking: Printed classified information shall be marked accordingly. The classification note "internal use" or 
"confidential" shall be placed on the title page and/or in the footer of the document.
Electronic Information Tagging: Electronic information and data should be tagged with the available metadata.
Device Labeling: In order to keep the administrative effort within manageable limits, the devices carrying data are not labeled. 
Employees are instructed to treat such devices and mobile devices as if they contained classified information.
Access Control: Access to information categorized as "confidential" is given on a "need-to-know" basis, i.e., an individual only receives 
access to such information to the extent necessary for the performance of his or her work. Information categorized as "internal use" 
should be available to employees by default.
Privileged Users: Classified information is only made available to privileged users. In the case of electronically stored information, 
appropriate authorizations must be assigned.
Security of Devices: Devices carrying data and devices on which classified information is stored shall be kept securely locked or 
password protected (e.g., employee laptops should not be locked, but should be password protected).
Data Deletion: If classified information on data carriers and devices is to be deleted, it should be done in line Asset Management Poli
cy | 3.13 Disposal of Media and Devices and lead to the permanent destruction of such information.
Default Classification: Documents without a label should by default be treated as "Internal Use" unless they are marketing or sales 
materials or materials intended to be available publicly or for selected external parties (which should be verified with the document 
owner).
These generic requirements ensure that information is classified, labeled, reviewed, and protected appropriately, maintaining the security 
and integrity of the company's data throughout its lifecycle.
3.2 Data Classification Scheme
Data classification, in the context of information security, is the classification of data based on its level of sensitivity and the impact to the 
company should that data be disclosed, altered, or destroyed without authorization. The classification of data helps determine what baseline 
security controls are appropriate for safeguarding that data. All data should be classified into one of the following classifications:
3.2.1 Confidential/Restricted Data
Data should be classified as Confidential/Restricted when the unauthorized disclosure, alteration, or destruction of that data could cause a 
serious or significant level of risk to the company or its customers. Examples of sensitive data include data protected by state or federal 
privacy regulations (e.g., PHI & PII) and data protected by confidentiality agreements. The highest level of security controls should be 
applied to Confidential/Restricted Data:
Access Restrictions: Disclosure or access to Confidential/Restricted data is limited to specific use by individuals with a legitimate need-
to-know. Explicit authorization by the CISO is required for access due to legal, contractual, privacy, or other constraints.
Protection Measures: Must be protected to prevent loss, theft, unauthorized access, and/or unauthorized disclosure.
Data Destruction: Must be destroyed when no longer needed. Destruction must be in accordance with company policies and 
procedures.

Incident Response: Will require specific methodologies, procedures, and reporting requirements for the response and handling of 
incidents.
3.2.2 Internal Use Data
Data should be classified as Internal Use when the unauthorized disclosure, alteration, or destruction of that data could result in a moderate 
level of risk to the company or its customers. This includes proprietary, ethical, or privacy considerations. Data must be protected from 
unauthorized access, modification, transmission, storage, or other use. This applies even though there may not be a civil statute requiring 
this protection. Internal Use Data is restricted to personnel who have a legitimate reason to access it. By default, all data that is not explicitly 
classified as Confidential/Restricted or Public data should be treated as Internal Use data. A reasonable level of security controls should be 
applied to Internal Use Data.
3.2.3 Public Data
Data should be classified as Public when the unauthorized disclosure, alteration, or destruction of that data would result in little or no risk to 
the company and its customers. It is further defined as information with no existing local, national, or international legal restrictions on 
access or usage. While little or no controls are required to protect the confidentiality of Public data, some level of control is required to 
prevent unauthorized alteration or destruction of Public Data.
3.2.4 De-identified Data
The company will de-identify data as a tool to remove personal information from data that it collects, uses, archives, and shares with other 
organizations. The de-identification process will allow the removal of direct identifiers, including all unique identifying numbers, 
characteristics, or codes. If a data set contains any amount or type of personal information, it will not be considered de-identified.
This data classification scheme ensures that all data handled by the company is appropriately classified based on its sensitivity and 
potential impact. By assigning one of the defined classifications, the company can implement suitable security controls to protect the data, 
thereby maintaining data confidentiality, integrity, and availability.

The goal of information security, as stated in the Information Security Policy, is to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of

compromised.
