1 Purpose and Scope
1.1 Purpose
The Asset Management Policy (further - the policy) defines requirements for managing and properly tracking assets owned, managed, and 
under the control of Squirro AG (further - the company). Additionally, the policy establishes a framework and guidelines for all employees, 
contractors, and third-party vendors who handle company IT assets.
1.2 Scope
This policy applies to all physical and digital assets owned, managed, or under the control of the company. This includes, but is not limited 
to, servers, workstations, laptops, networking equipment, virtual machines, and any data stored or processed by these assets.
2 Roles and Responsibilities
2.1 Asset Owners
Asset Owners are individuals or entities assigned the responsibility to control the entire lifecycle of the asset. They must ensure the proper 
management, classification, and protection of the asset and periodically review access restrictions and classifications. Responsibilities of 
Asset Owners include:
Asset Inventory Management: Ensure that all assigned assets are accurately documented and updated in the asset management 
system.

Asset Classification and Protection: Classify assets according to their value and sensitivity, and implement appropriate protection 
measures.
Access Control Reviews: Periodically review and update access restrictions to ensure only authorized individuals have access to the 
assets.
Lifecycle Management: Oversee the asset's lifecycle, including acquisition, usage, maintenance, and disposal.
Incident Reporting: Report any incidents involving the asset, such as loss, theft, or unauthorized access, to the IT department.
2.2 Systems Administrators
The Systems Administrators are responsible for maintaining the asset inventory, ensuring assets are wiped clean of data before disposal, 
managing access controls, and implementing baseline security configurations. Responsibilities of Systems Administrators include:
Asset Inventory Maintenance: Keep the asset management system up-to-date with accurate records of all physical and digital assets.
Data Sanitization: Ensure that all data is securely wiped from assets before they are disposed of or repurposed.
Access Control Management: Implement and manage access controls to protect assets from unauthorized access.
Security Configuration: Apply baseline security configurations to all assets to ensure they meet the company's security standards.
Technical Support: Provide technical support for asset-related issues, including setup, maintenance, and troubleshooting.
Compliance Monitoring: Monitor compliance with the asset management policy and report any deviations to the relevant authorities.
2.3 End Users
End Users are responsible for adhering to this policy, properly using and safeguarding company assets, and reporting any incidents of loss, 
theft, or unauthorized access to assets. Responsibilities of End Users include:
Proper Use of Assets: Use company assets in accordance with company policies and for authorized purposes only.
Asset Safeguarding: Take reasonable steps to protect assets from damage, loss, or theft.
Incident Reporting: Report any incidents involving asset loss, theft, or unauthorized access to the IT department immediately.
Compliance with Policies: Follow all guidelines and procedures outlined in the asset management policy.
Training Participation: Participate in training sessions related to asset management and security to stay informed about best practices 
and company policies.
These roles and responsibilities ensure that all assets are properly managed, protected, and used in compliance with company policies, 
supporting the overall security and operational efficiency of the organization.
3 Policy
3.1 General Statement
The following guidelines ensure proper handling, protection, and tracking of media assets throughout their lifecycle:
Marking of Media Assets: All copies of media assets will be clearly marked for the attention of the authorized recipient, to ensure that 
only authorized individuals handle media assets, reducing the risk of unauthorized access or loss.
Consistency in Information Protection: Temporary or permanent copies of information will be at a level consistent with the protection 
of the original information, to maintains the security and integrity of information, regardless of its format or storage medium.
Access Restrictions: Access to each asset will be restricted based on the asset's classification, to ensure that sensitive assets are only 
accessible to authorized personnel, protecting against unauthorized access and potential data breaches.
Record of Authorized Recipients: A record of authorized recipients of assets will be established and maintained, to track who has 
access to specific assets, aiding in accountability and security management.
Tracking Disposal/Replacement of Assets: The disposal/replacement of physical and virtual assets will be tracked, whether it is due to 
depreciation, expiring leases or agreements, obsolescence/end of support, loss, or other reasons, to ensure that asset lifecycle events 
are documented, allowing for proper management and replacement planning.

Reporting and Compliance: A reporting function will support auditing and monitoring for IT compliance with this standard, to facilitates 
regular audits and monitoring to ensure compliance with asset management policies and standards.
These guidelines ensure that all media assets are appropriately marked, protected, and tracked, providing a comprehensive approach to 
asset management and compliance.
3.2 Asset Inventory Standard
An asset inventory process must be in place to support the technological management of critical business processes and to meet legal and 
regulatory requirements. The inventory process will also support the discovery, management, and replacement/disposal of all assets. It will 
further facilitate the identification and removal of any illegal or unauthorized software, asset, or processes found in the company 
environment. 
To accomplish these goals, all physical and virtual assets under company management or control (including external assets such as end-
user devices, network devices, non-computing/IoT devices, and servers) will be listed in an inventory that will include:
Unique Identifier or Name of the Asset: All physical and virtual assets under company management or control will be listed in an 
inventory with a unique identifier or name.
Naming and Asset Classification: Naming and asset classification will be done according to legal, value, and business requirements to 
protect restricted information sharing.
Description of the Asset: A detailed description of the asset.
Purpose of the Asset: The role the asset has in supporting critical business processes and in meeting legal or regulatory requirements, 
if applicable.
Entity Responsible for the Asset: Identification of the individual or department responsible for the asset.
Sensitive Information Designation: Assets that contain sensitive information (e.g., PHI, personal data, etc.) shall be clearly designated 
as such for tracking purposes.
Asset Classification: Classification of the asset, if applicable, as prescribed in the Data Classification Policy.
Hosted Asset Tracking Solution: Use a hosted asset tracking solution for servers, switches, data center asset tracking, and racks that 
employ passive radio frequency identification (RFID), global positioning system (GPS), and/or Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) technologies.
Location and Cloud Service Utilized: The physical location and the cloud service utilized, when assets are stored in a cloud computing 
environment.
Listed Data from a Cloud Service: Data from a cloud service customer and any data derived from the provided cloud service.
This structured inventory ensures that all assets are accounted for, managed effectively, and protected according to their classification and 
importance to the company's operations.
3.3 Asset Ownership
The company will assign an owner to each asset when the asset is created or transferred to the company. The asset owner can be an 
individual or an entity with approved management responsibility to control the whole lifecycle of the asset; the asset owner will not 
necessarily have property rights to the asset.
Asset Ownership Assignment: The company will assign an owner to each asset when the asset is created or transferred to the 
company, ensuring clear responsibility and accountability for each asset from its inception.
Responsibility of Asset Owners: The asset owner will be responsible for the proper management of the asset over the asset's entire 
lifecycle, or until a new owner is assigned to the asset, guaranteeing continuous and consistent management of the asset.
Inventory Management: Ensure that assets are inventoried, maintaining a comprehensive and up-to-date record of all assets.
Classification and Protection: Ensure that assets are appropriately classified and protected, protecting assets according to their 
classification, ensuring appropriate security measures are in place.
Access and Classification Review: Define and periodically review access restrictions and classification to important assets, taking into 
account applicable access control policies, ensuring that access controls and classifications remain current and effective.

Proper Handling of Asset Deletion/Destruction: Ensure proper handling when the asset is deleted/destroyed, ensuring secure and 
compliant disposal or destruction of assets, protecting sensitive information.
These guidelines ensure that asset ownership is clearly defined and managed, providing a structured approach to the lifecycle management 
of assets.
3.4 Physical Asset Inventory
The company leverages a SaaS-based asset management system, Drata, to maintain an inventory of all company-owned physical 
computing equipment, including but not limited to:
Servers: All servers owned by the company will be listed in the inventory.
Workstations: Workstations used by employees will be tracked and managed.
Laptops: Laptops provided to employees will be included in the inventory.
Printers: All printers used within the company will be listed.
Networking Equipment: Networking devices such as routers and switches will be tracked.
All company-owned devices are subject to a complete data wipe if deemed necessary, such as in the case of device infection or repurpose. 
This data wipe will be carried out by the IT manager, ensuring the protection of sensitive information and compliance with company data 
security policies.
3.5 Digital Asset Inventory
The company uses Drata's automated system to query across our cloud-based infrastructure to obtain detailed records of all digital assets, 
including but not limited to:
Virtual Machines: Digital records of virtual machines will be maintained.
Virtual Servers: All virtual servers used within the company will be tracked.
Virtual Repositories: Repositories for code and other digital resources will be included.
Security Agents: Security agents and their deployment details will be recorded.
Source Code Repositories: Repositories containing source code will be tracked.
User Accounts: All user accounts within the digital infrastructure will be documented.
The records are stored in a database system maintained by the company. Records are tagged with owner/project and classification when 
applicable. All records are kept up to date through automation via Drata, ensuring accuracy and comprehensive asset management.
3.6 Asset Retirement Standard
The information resource owner determines when an asset is no longer needed or is obsolete and can be retired. 
Replacement of Assets Supporting Legal/Regulatory Requirements: If the asset to be replaced/retired supports mandatory legal 
and regulatory requirements of critical business processes, the information resource owner must ensure that any replacement asset can 
support these processes before the current asset is retired.
Data Retention Requirements: Before retiring/replacing any asset that retains data, data retention requirements for all data stored or 
managed by that asset must be reviewed, and a plan for complying with all applicable data retention requirements must be developed 
and executed. This ensures compliance with legal and regulatory standards.
Data Migration and Testing: Any data subject to data retention requirements must be migrated to an appropriate destination and tested 
for appropriateness, completeness, accessibility, and retrievability from the destination before the original data is deleted from the 
original asset as part of the system retirement process. This is particularly important for assets that manage data subject to 
legal/regulatory scrutiny.
These guidelines ensure the proper and compliant retirement of assets, maintaining data integrity and regulatory compliance throughout the 
process.

3.7 Baseline Configurations for Endpoints
The following baseline security requirements will be implemented for the protection of endpoint assets, including company-issued laptops, 
workstations, and mobile devices as applicable:
Antivirus and Anti-Malware Tools: Antivirus and anti-malware tools will be deployed on endpoint devices (e.g., workstations, laptops, 
and mobile devices). These tools will be configured to automatically receive updates, run scans, and alert appropriate personnel of 
viruses or malware.
Password Manager: A password manager will be installed on all company-issued devices to ensure secure management of passwords.
Hard-Disk Encryption: Hard-disk encryption will be enabled on all company-issued devices to protect data at rest.
Automated Operating System (OS) Updates: Automated OS updates will be enabled on company-issued devices to install security 
patches and maintain system security.
Browser Testing Tool: If browser add-ons are approved and installed, a browser testing tool will be installed to assess the security of 
the add-on.
Controls for Removable Media: Controls are in place to restrict the use of removable media to authorized personnel only, ensuring that 
data transfer through removable media is secure and monitored.
These baseline configurations ensure that all endpoint devices are equipped with essential security measures to protect against malware, 
unauthorized access, and data breaches, thereby maintaining the overall security posture of the company's IT environment.
3.8 System Hardening Standards
Baseline security configuration standards for all system components will be documented in accordance with industry-accepted system 
hardening standards or vendor hardening recommendations. These standards will be updated as needed when vulnerabilities are identified 
and verified to be in place before or immediately after a system component is connected to a production environment.
Device Best Practices and Hardening Standards: Manufacturer-provided hardening and best practice guides will be employed to 
ensure all device installations are properly guarded from vulnerabilities and unauthorized attempts to access the systems.
CIS Benchmarks: Center for Internet Security (CIS) benchmarks are utilized where possible for system hardening guidance (CIS 
Benchmarks™).
Vendor Supplied Defaults: Vendor supplied defaults, including usernames, passwords, and any other common settings that may result 
in unauthorized attempts to access the systems, will be disabled or changed in accordance with best practices and hardening guidelines.
Removal of Insecure and Unnecessary Services: Insecure and unnecessary services, protocols, daemons, and functions in system 
components, and all unnecessary functionality (e.g., scripts, drivers, features, subsystems, file systems, interfaces, unused web servers, 
etc.) will be removed or disabled.
Local Passwords: Local passwords, when required, will be randomly generated and securely stored in the approved password 
management system.
Current Patches: Current patches will be installed to ensure systems are up-to-date and protected against known vulnerabilities.
Malware Protection: Malware protection will be implemented to safeguard systems against malicious software.
Logging: Logging will be enabled to monitor and record system activities for security and troubleshooting purposes.
Two-Factor Authentication: Two-factor authentication should be used whenever available/supported on the device platform to enhance 
security.
Location-Aware Technologies: Where applicable, use location-aware technologies to validate connection authentication integrity 
based on known equipment locations.
These system hardening standards ensure that all system components are securely configured, reducing vulnerabilities and protecting 
against unauthorized access and other security threats.
3.9 Infrastructure Virtualization Security
The following guidelines ensure the security of virtualized infrastructure within the company:

LVM Images and Snapshots: LVM images and snapshots are restricted to authorized locations. This ensures that only authorized 
personnel can access and manage these critical virtual resources.
Backup Systems and Failover Capabilities: Backup systems and failover capabilities are established to ensure data integrity and 
availability in case of system failures.
VM Tagging: VMs are tagged based on their sensitivity or risk level for easier identification. This aids in the effective management and 
security of virtual machines.
Change Management Process: A formal change management process and approval is followed for creating, storing, and using VM 
images. This ensures that all changes are tracked and approved, maintaining system integrity.
Consistent Security Policies: Security policies and configurations are consistent across both physical and virtual networks. This 
ensures a unified security approach and simplifies management.
Consistent Security Technologies: Security technologies across both physical and virtual networks are consistent with the policy 
management and enforcement framework. This provides a cohesive security strategy across all network environments.
Firewalls: Physical or virtual firewalls are utilized to separate groups of VMs from other hosted groups. This segmentation enhances 
security by isolating different virtual environments.
Access Controls: Access controls for each trust level are established, governing access to physical and virtual management and 
security systems. This ensures that only authorized users can access and manage critical systems.
These guidelines ensure that the virtualized infrastructure is securely managed, maintaining the integrity and availability of virtual resources 
while protecting against unauthorized access and potential security threats.3.9 Infrastructure Configuration and Maintenance
3.10 Infrastructure Configuration and Maintenance
The following guidelines ensure the proper configuration and maintenance of the company's infrastructure:
3.10.1 Internal Workstation and Server Patching
Periodic Evaluation: Operating system patches/upgrades are evaluated periodically to identify necessary updates.
Criticality-Based Installation: Operating system and security patches/upgrades are installed based on their criticality, ensuring that 
high-priority updates are applied promptly.
Off-Peak Installation: Operating system patches/upgrades are installed during off-peak hours to minimize disruption to business 
processes.
3.10.2 Internal Infrastructure Patching
Periodic Evaluation: Infrastructure (routers, switches, virtual hosts, etc.) patches/upgrades are evaluated as they become available 
from vendors.
Criticality-Based Installation: Infrastructure patches/upgrades are installed based on their criticality, ensuring timely application of 
critical updates.
Lab Environment Review: Infrastructure patches/upgrades are reviewed and approved via a lab environment when possible/practical 
to verify their impact and stability.
Off-Peak Installation: Infrastructure patches/upgrades are installed during off-peak hours to minimize disruption to business processes.
Redundant Systems Patching: When applicable, redundant systems are patched/upgraded one device at a time to ensure no impact 
on shared services.
Change Management Procedures: Networking hardware/software updates follow the regular change management procedures to 
ensure consistency and traceability.
3.10.3 Infrastructure Support Documentation
Configuration Standards: Configuration standards for the setup of all infrastructure devices are in place and are formally documented 
as necessary. This ensures consistent and secure configuration of all devices.

These guidelines ensure that the company's infrastructure is regularly updated, securely configured, and maintained, thereby supporting the 
integrity, availability, and reliability of critical business processes.
3.11 Capacity Management
The following guidelines ensure that the company's systems have adequate capacity to meet current and future business needs:
Identification of Capacity Requirements: Capacity requirements of systems will be identified in line with the business criticality of the 
concerned system. This ensures that critical systems are prioritized and adequately resourced.
System Tuning and Monitoring: System tuning and monitoring will be applied to ensure and improve (when needed) the availability 
and efficiency of systems. This helps in maintaining optimal system performance.
Detective Controls: Detective controls will be put in place to indicate problems as they occur, enabling prompt identification and 
resolution of issues.
Future Capacity Projections: Projections of future capacity requirements will account for new business and system requirements and 
current and projected trends in the company's information processing capabilities. This proactive approach helps in planning and scaling 
resources effectively.
Monitoring Utilization and Identifying Trends: To mitigate bottlenecks and dependence on key personnel presenting a threat to 
system security or services, managers must monitor the utilization of key system resources, identify trends in usage, and account for any 
resources that may have long procurement lead times or high costs.
Providing Sufficient Capacity: Providing sufficient capacity will be achieved by increasing capacity or by reducing demand. This 
includes:
Deletion of Obsolete Data: Removing outdated data to free up disk space.
Decommissioning of Applications/Systems: Decommissioning applications, systems, databases, or environments that are no 
longer needed.
Optimizing Batch Processes and Schedules: Improving batch processing efficiency and scheduling.
Optimizing Application Logic/Database Queries: Enhancing the efficiency of application logic or database queries.
Restricting Non-Business Critical Services: Denying or restricting bandwidth for resource-hungry services if these are not 
business critical (e.g., video streaming).
Managing Capacity Demand: Actively managing and balancing capacity demand.
Provisioning New Server Instances: Provisioning new server instances when capacity thresholds are met to ensure continuous 
availability and performance.
These guidelines ensure that the company effectively manages system capacity, thereby maintaining the performance, availability, and 
reliability of critical business processes and IT services.
3.12 Management of Media
The following guidelines ensure the proper management of removable media and the sanitization of media to protect data integrity and 
confidentiality:
3.12.1 Removable Media
For the proper management of removable media, the following steps will be taken, when applicable:
Authorization for Removal: Authorization will be required for removing media from company facilities or assets, when necessary and 
practical. This ensures that only authorized individuals can remove media, reducing the risk of unauthorized access or loss.
Audit Trail: A record of the removal will be kept for an audit trail, providing a clear record of who has removed media and when.
Log for ePHI Media: A separate log or a clearly-defined section of the overall record shall be designated specifically for media 
containing ePHI, ensuring compliance with regulatory requirements.
Unrecoverable Content on Reusable Media: Contents of any reusable media being retired or replaced will be made unrecoverable, 
protecting sensitive data from unauthorized access.

Storage and Security: All media will be stored and secured in accordance with manufacturers' specifications, ensuring proper handling 
and protection.
Cryptographic Protection: Cryptographic techniques should be used to protect data on removable media to maintain integrity and 
confidentiality.
Mitigation of Media Degradation: Media degradation will be mitigated by transferring stored data to fresh media before becoming 
unreadable.
Multiple Copies for Data Protection: Coincidental data damage or loss will be mitigated by making multiple copies of valuable data on 
separate media.
Business Reason for Enabling Drives: Removable media drives will only be enabled if there is a business reason for it, reducing the 
risk of unauthorized use.
Monitoring Information Transfer: Transfer of information to removable media will be monitored to ensure compliance with company 
policies and security standards.
3.12.2 Return of Assets Upon Termination
The termination process includes the return of all previously issued physical and electronic assets owned by or entrusted to the company, as 
outlined in the Employment Terms and Conditions, Code of Conduct  and System Access Management Policy:
Return and Erasure of Equipment: If company equipment was purchased by an employee or third-party user, or personal equipment 
was used, all relevant information must be transferred to the company and securely erased from the equipment.
Monitoring and Control of Information Copying: Unauthorized copying of information by employees and contractors will be monitored 
and controlled during the termination period.
3.12.3 Media Sanitization
Media sanitization procedures are in place to ensure that when data is removed, it cannot be retrieved or reconstructed:
Definition of System Media: System media will be defined, indicating when they require sanitization prior to disposal, release from 
organization control, or reuse.
Application of Sanitization: Sanitization applies to all media, digital or non-digital, ensuring comprehensive protection of data.
Level of Sanitization: The level of sanitization used will be determined by the classification or security category of the information.
Sanitization Techniques: Sanitization techniques will include clearing, purging, cryptographic erase, de-identification of PII, and 
destruction.
Review and Approval: All sanitization and disposal actions will be reviewed, approved, tracked, documented, and verified to ensure 
compliance with company policies and security standards.
Sanitization of Portable Storage Devices: Prior to connecting portable storage devices to the system, the devices will be sanitized 
through non-destructive techniques. Portable storage devices will be sanitized when specific scenarios arise (e.g., before reuse, 
disposal).
Regular Review and Testing: Sanitization procedures and equipment will be reviewed and tested regularly to ensure that the intended 
sanitization is being achieved.
These guidelines ensure the secure management and sanitization of media, protecting sensitive information from unauthorized access and 
ensuring compliance with regulatory requirements.
3.13 Disposal of Media and Devices
The secure disposal of media and devices is a critical component of information security management. This policy outlines the procedures 
for the disposal of electronic and non-electronic storage media and devices within the company to ensure that sensitive data is permanently 
and irretrievably deleted. By adhering to these guidelines, the company ensures compliance with regulatory requirements, protects data 
integrity, and mitigates the risk of unauthorized access.

3.13.1 Disposal of Electronic Storage Media
Handling and Disposal: Data media that need to be disposed of must either be handed over to the IT Department or placed in the 
containers provided for this purpose.
Permanent and Irretrievable Deletion:
If storage media are disposed of, the data must be permanently and irretrievably deleted by IT. The following procedures are 
accepted as permanent and irretrievable deletion:
7-fold wiping with a suitable deletion program.
Physical destruction of the storage medium.
Destruction through degaussing.
Designated Storage Prior to Final Disposal: If the storage media are stored prior to final disposal, this must be done at a designated, 
labeled place in order to avoid confusion with data media that can be reused.
3.13.2 Disposal of Non-Electronic Storage Media
Classification-Based Disposal: Non-electronic storage media must be disposed of according to their classification.
Unclassified Paper: Unclassified paper is disposed of together with the wastepaper.
Shredding: Shredders are available (owned by the company or provided by an office management company) for individual documents.
3.13.3 Disposal of PCs and Multi-Functional Devices
Wiping Storage Media: Storage media in devices such as PCs, laptops, or multi-functional devices should be wiped.
Physical Destruction: If wiping is not possible, the storage media must be removed and physically destroyed.
Contractual Agreement for Multi-Functional Devices: In the case of multi-functional devices, a contractual agreement must be 
concluded with the service provider on how a suitable extinguishing procedure can be implemented before the device leaves the 
premises.
Designated Storage for Disposal: Equipment intended for disposal must be stored in a designated and labeled place.
3.14 Asset Management Procedures
The following guidelines ensure the proper management of assets throughout their lifecycle, from acquisition to disposal. This 
comprehensive approach guarantees that all assets are appropriately documented, managed, maintained, and audited to support the 
company's operational efficiency and regulatory compliance.
3.14.1 Asset Acquisition
All assets acquired must be documented, including details of purchase, vendor information, and relevant warranty details. The asset must 
be entered into the asset management system upon receipt to ensure accurate tracking and management from the outset.
Details Required: Information to be documented includes purchase date, cost, vendor contact information, and warranty expiration.
Integration into Asset Management System: Ensures that all new assets are seamlessly integrated into the existing asset inventory 
for consistent tracking.
3.14.2 Asset Tagging
Each asset will be tagged with a unique identifier to facilitate tracking and management. This identifier will be recorded in the asset inventory 
system, ensuring each asset can be easily identified and monitored.
Tagging Procedure: Tags should be durable and placed in a location that is easily accessible for inventory checks.
Inventory System Recording: The unique identifier must be logged in the asset management system along with relevant asset details 
for comprehensive tracking.

3.14.3 Asset Usage
Employees and contractors must use assets in compliance with company policies and only for authorized purposes. Misuse or unauthorized 
use of assets is prohibited and may result in disciplinary action, ensuring assets are used appropriately and securely.
User Training: Employees and contractors will receive training on proper asset usage and the importance of compliance with company 
policies.
Monitoring and Enforcement: Regular monitoring will be conducted to ensure compliance, and violations will be addressed promptly to 
maintain asset security and integrity.
3.14.4 Asset Maintenance
Regular maintenance schedules will be established for all assets to ensure they remain in good working condition. This includes software 
updates, hardware inspections, and preventive maintenance, which help prolong the lifespan and reliability of assets.
Preventive Maintenance: Regular checks and updates to prevent issues before they occur.
Maintenance Documentation: All maintenance activities will be recorded in the asset management system for future reference and 
compliance.
3.14.5 Asset Audits
Periodic will be conducted to verify the accuracy of the asset inventory and ensure compliance with this policy. Discrepancies will be 
investigated, and corrective actions taken as necessary, maintaining the integrity of the asset management process.
Audit Schedule: Regular intervals for audits will be established, such as quarterly or annually, depending on the criticality of the assets.
Audit Procedures: Audits will include physical checks of assets, reconciliation with inventory records, and validation of proper usage 
and maintenance practices.
Corrective Actions: Any discrepancies found during audits will be promptly addressed, and necessary adjustments will be made to 
improve the asset management process.
These guidelines ensure that all assets are properly managed throughout their lifecycle, supporting the company's operational efficiency and 
compliance with regulatory requirements. By maintaining detailed records, conducting regular maintenance and audits, and enforcing proper 
usage policies, the company can safeguard its assets and ensure their optimal performance and longevity.

Description
The Logging and Monitoring Policy establishes the requirements for audit logging and continuous monitoring of system activities within Squirro AG. It outlines how sensitive systems
and data must be tracked, including logging events such as network connections, authentication, administrative actions, and security incidents. The policy also specifies the key
elements that each log should contain, such as action types, system identifiers, and timestamps. Additionally, it includes requirements for clock synchronization, protection of audit logs
from tampering, and regular reviews to ensure logs are properly monitored for security breaches. Monitoring critical security controls ensures prompt detection, response, and
remediation of any security failures or incidents, thus maintaining system integrity and compliance.

4.4 Approvals

1 Purpose and Scope
3.1 Purpose
The Logging and Monitoring Policy (further - the policy) defines the requirements and procedures for logging system activities and 
monitoring audit trails at Squirro AG (further - the company). Additionally, the policy establishes a structured approach to ensure that all 
system components, including applications, infrastructure, network, and security tools, are monitored for security, compliance, and 
operational effectiveness. The policy applies to all employees, contractors, and third parties who access, manage, or interact with the 
company's IT resources.
3.2 Scope
This policy applies to all system components at the company, including:
Applications
Infrastructure (including cloud infrastructure)
Network components
Security tools and utilities
Any other components that could impact the security of the company and the data it processes
2 Roles and Responsibilities
2.1 Chief Information Security Officer (CISO)
The CISO is responsible for overseeing the overall security framework and ensuring that logging and monitoring processes align with 
security objectives.
Policy Enforcement: Ensures that the Logging and Monitoring Policy is implemented across all systems and components.
Incident Response: Coordinates responses to incidents detected through logs, ensuring timely action and compliance with regulations.
Monitoring Oversight: Regularly reviews monitoring mechanisms and reports to ensure the effectiveness of controls and compliance 
with internal standards.
The CISO plays a critical role in maintaining the integrity and security of the company's audit and monitoring practices.
2.2 Chief Information Officer (CIO)
The CIO is responsible for ensuring that technical infrastructure and systems meet the requirements outlined in the policy.
Infrastructure Alignment: Ensures that systems, network components, and applications support audit logging and monitoring 
requirements.
Log Protection: Works to safeguard logs by implementing access controls and ensuring proper backup and storage mechanisms.
System Management: Ensures all critical security control systems, such as IDS/IPS and network security controls, are properly 
monitored.
The following roles and responsibilities are to be developed and subsequently assigned to authorized personnel within the company 
regarding implementation of this document.
Groups and individuals definitions are given according to the Information Security Organization Policy .

The CIO ensures that the company's systems comply with the logging and monitoring requirements.
2.3 Responsible for Information Security (RIS)
The RIS manages day-to-day information security practices and ensures logging and monitoring are effectively implemented and 
maintained.
Daily Monitoring: Oversees routine monitoring activities, including log review and anomaly detection.
Incident Handling: Coordinates with the CISO and CIO during security incidents, ensuring that logs are analyzed, and proper 
responses are initiated.
Reporting: Generates reports based on logs and monitoring data to ensure compliance and highlight areas needing improvement.
The RIS ensures that logging and monitoring tasks are consistently carried out to maintain a secure environment.
2.4 System Administrators
System Administrators are responsible for implementing the logging mechanisms on systems and ensuring proper retention and protection.
Log Management: Sets up, configures, and maintains logging mechanisms across all critical systems.
Log Review: Ensures logs are reviewed regularly and securely backed up to central repositories.
Change Detection: Implements change-detection mechanisms to prevent unauthorized modifications to logs.
System Administrators ensure the operational integrity of the logging and monitoring systems.
2.5 Employees and Contractors
All employees and contractors are responsible for adhering to the logging and monitoring policies as outlined.
Incident Reporting: Report any incidents or suspicious activities observed in the logs.
Policy Compliance: Follow the procedures for handling sensitive data and logs as described in the policy.
Security Awareness: Participate in security awareness training related to logging and monitoring practices.
Employees and contractors play an important role in maintaining the integrity and security of the company's logging system by complying 
with the policy.
3 Policy
3.1 Event Logs
All systems at the company that access or handle sensitive information, accept network connections, manage access control (authentication 
and authorization), or impact the security of the environment (e.g., anti-malware utilities, firewalls) must record and retain audit logs. These 
logs must provide sufficient detail to answer the following questions:
What activity was performed?
Who performed the activity?
Where, when, and how was it performed (including the tools used)?
What was the status, outcome, or result of the activity?
By ensuring that logs capture this information, the company enhances its ability to monitor, review, and respond to security events, ensuring 
the integrity and security of its systems.
3.2 Logged Activities
Log records must be created for the following activities:

Sensitive Information Access:
Attempts to create, read, update, or delete sensitive information, including confidential authentication data such as passwords.
Network Connections:
Initiating or accepting a network connection.
User Authentication and Authorization:
User login and logout, as well as any changes to access rights.
Invalid Logical Access Attempts:
All unauthorized or failed logical access attempts.
Administrative Actions:
All actions performed by individuals with administrative or elevated privileges.
Attempts to grant, modify, or revoke access rights (e.g., adding a new user or group, changing user privilege levels, modifying file or 
database permissions).
Changes to firewall rules, user privileges, and database object permissions.
Modifications of administrative access, including user password changes and elevation of privileges.
Audit Log Access:
All access to audit logs, including actions such as starting, stopping, or pausing audit logs.
System-Level Changes:
Creation and deletion of system-level objects.
Changes in system, network, or services configuration, including the installation of software patches, updates, or other installed 
software modifications.
System Events:
Application and process events, such as startup, shutdown, or restart.
Application process failure, abnormal termination, or resource exhaustion (e.g., CPU, memory, network bandwidth, disk space).
Failures of critical services (e.g., DHCP, DNS), hardware faults, or hardware malfunctions.
Detection of Suspicious/Malicious Activity:
Detection and logging of potential security threats, including alerts from intrusion detection systems (IDS), intrusion prevention 
systems (IPS), web application firewalls, anti-malware systems, or anti-spyware tools.
By capturing these logged activities, the company ensures full visibility into system operations and enhances the ability to respond to 
potential security incidents or system malfunctions.
3.3 Log Elements
Each log must identify or contain the following elements to ensure thorough audit trails and log correlation where feasible (content may 
depend on system):
Type of Action      The specific action performed, such as authorize, create, read, update, delete, or network connection 
initiation. Includes whether the action was successful or failed. 
Subsystem           The process or transaction name responsible for performing the action. Examples include a system 
service or application transaction. 
Identifiers         Identifying information for the subject requesting the action, such as user name, computer name, IP 
address, MAC address. These identifiers should be standardized for easy correlation. 
Object of Action    Identifies what the action was performed on, such as file names accessed, records from a database, or 
specific network resources affected. 
ElementDescription

This structured approach ensures that logs provide comprehensive visibility into system activities, enabling effective monitoring, auditing, 
and security investigations.
3.4 Clock Synchronization
To ensure the accuracy of system logs, all system clocks must be synchronized using time-synchronization technology. The following 
requirements are mandatory for maintaining the integrity and consistency of audit logs:
Time Source: Logs must rely on accurate time sources, either International Atomic Time (TAI) or Coordinated Universal Time 
(UTC), to ensure uniformity across systems.
Network Time Protocol (NTP): All servers and critical infrastructure must use NTP to synchronize their clocks with a central time server. 
This ensures that the timestamps in audit logs are consistent across the environment.
Time Synchronization Settings:
Access Control: Time synchronization settings will be restricted to authorized personnel only. Changes to the time settings must be 
limited to those with a business need and appropriate permissions.
Logging Changes: Any modification to time settings on critical systems must be logged, including details of the personnel making 
the change and the reason for it.
Monitoring: System logs must be continuously monitored to ensure that no unauthorized or unintended changes to the time settings 
occur. Any detected discrepancies will be flagged and reviewed.
Auditing and Review: Regular reviews of time synchronization settings and logs will be conducted to detect any drift or misalignment in 
time stamps, ensuring the accuracy of all logged events.
This synchronization mechanism helps ensure that all log entries are recorded with accurate and consistent timestamps, which is essential 
for auditing, investigations, and compliance reporting.
3.5 Protection of Audit Logs
To ensure the integrity and security of audit logs, the following controls will be implemented to safeguard logs from tampering by individuals 
with elevated access or unauthorized users:
Access Control:
Restricted Access: Read access to audit logs will be strictly limited to personnel with a job-related need. Only authorized 
individuals responsible for monitoring or auditing system activity will be granted this access.
Administrator Restrictions: System administrators will be restricted from erasing, deactivating, or modifying logs of their own 
activities if possible. This ensures transparency and accountability for administrative actions.
Backup:
Centralized Backup: All audit log files, including those related to external-facing technologies, will be backed up to a secure, 
centralized internal log server or other secure media. These backups will be stored outside the direct control of system 
administrators to prevent manipulation.
Redundancy and Availability: Logs must be backed up on a regular basis, with redundancy measures in place to ensure log 
availability during recovery from failures or security incidents.
Before/After Values When applicable and feasible, records the before and after values of data elements that are updated as 
part of the action. 
Date and Time       The exact date and time the action was performed, including relevant time-zone information. For 
consistency, logs should use Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) when possible. 
Access Control Outcome Whether the action was allowed or denied by the system's access control mechanisms. 
Access Control Reason  In the event the action is denied, logs should contain descriptions or reason codes explaining why it 
was blocked. 

File Integrity Monitoring:
Change Detection: A file integrity monitoring (FIM) or change-detection mechanism will be employed to monitor and protect audit 
logs (where feasible based on system criticality, design and requirements). Any unauthorized or unexpected changes to the logs must 
generate real-time alerts.
Continuous Monitoring: All log data will be subjected to continuous monitoring, with alerts configured to detect suspicious or 
malicious activities targeting audit logs.
Review and Accountability:
Periodic Reviews: Logs related to privileged user activities, including system administrators and operators, will be reviewed 
regularly to ensure compliance with security policies and detect any misuse or unauthorized actions.
Accountability: All activities carried out by privileged users (e.g., system administrators) will be logged. These logs will be reviewed 
by security personnel and subjected to routine audits to maintain accountability.
Privileged Operations Logging:
Delegated Operations: In instances where privileged operations have been delegated to the company by third parties or customers, 
the performance of these operations will be logged and safeguarded. This ensures that all privileged actions are traceable and can 
be audited when necessary.
By implementing these protections, the integrity and availability of audit logs are maintained, ensuring they provide reliable evidence for 
audits, investigations, and security monitoring.
3.6 Monitoring
Failures in critical security control systems must be detected, alerted, and resolved promptly to maintain the integrity of the company's 
infrastructure. The systems that must be monitored include:
Network Security Controls: 
Intrusion Detection/Prevention Systems (IDS/IPS): Monitors network traffic for suspicious activities and responds to threats.
Firewalls: Ensures unauthorized network traffic is blocked, with real-time monitoring of firewall rule changes and suspicious 
connection attempts.
Access Controls: 
Physical Access Controls: Monitoring systems that track and alert on unauthorized physical access to sensitive areas such as data 
centers (not applicable for cloud environment, maintained by cloud provider).
Logical Access Controls: Ensuring that login attempts, failed logins, privilege escalations, and other access control mechanisms 
are actively monitored and alerting for unauthorized attempts.
Audit Logs: 
Automated Monitoring: Continuous monitoring of audit logs to detect anomalies, security breaches, and policy violations.
Periodic Reviews: Manual review of logs by authorized personnel to ensure adherence to company security policies and standards.
Change Detection Mechanisms: 
File Integrity Monitoring: Tracks and alerts on unauthorized changes to critical system files, configurations, and security settings.
System Configuration Monitoring: Detects any unsanctioned system changes, such as unauthorized software installations or 
misconfigurations.
Anti-malware Solutions: 
Threat Detection: Continuous monitoring for malware infections, suspicious activity, and potential threats across systems, with 
automatic alerts and incident reporting.
Failures identified within any of these critical control systems must be addressed promptly in accordance with the incident response 
policy. Actions include:
Restoring Security Functions:
Security functions must be immediately restored to minimize downtime and prevent further damage or compromise.
Documenting the Failure:

Duration: Accurately recording the start and end times of the security failure.
Cause Identification: Investigating the root cause of the failure and documenting it comprehensively.
Addressing Security Issues:
Impact Assessment: Identifying and addressing any security risks or vulnerabilities exposed by the failure.
Remediation: Implementing immediate fixes to resolve the issues, whether it is through patching, reconfiguring, or updating systems.
Evaluating Future Risk:
Preventative Actions: Implementing controls or improvements to prevent the reoccurrence of the failure.
Resuming Monitoring: Ensuring that the affected systems and controls are returned to full monitoring status to continue 
safeguarding against future incidents.
Incident Reporting:
Security incidents resulting from control failures must be logged, reported, and shared with relevant stakeholders, including IT and 
security teams, ensuring transparency and prompt action.
By enforcing continuous monitoring and establishing robust incident response mechanisms, the company ensures that failures in security 
controls are detected and addressed efficiently to minimize the impact on its operations and data security.

1 Purpose and Scope
3.1 Purpose
The Logging and Monitoring Policy (further - the policy) defines the requirements and procedures for logging system activities and 
monitoring audit trails at Squirro AG (further - the company). Additionally, the policy establishes a structured approach to ensure that all 
system components, including applications, infrastructure, network, and security tools, are monitored for security, compliance, and 
operational effectiveness. The policy applies to all employees, contractors, and third parties who access, manage, or interact with the 
company's IT resources.
3.2 Scope
This policy applies to all system components at the company, including:
Applications
Infrastructure (including cloud infrastructure)
Network components
Security tools and utilities
Any other components that could impact the security of the company and the data it processes
2 Roles and Responsibilities
2.1 Chief Information Security Officer (CISO)
The CISO is responsible for overseeing the overall security framework and ensuring that logging and monitoring processes align with 
security objectives.
Policy Enforcement: Ensures that the Logging and Monitoring Policy is implemented across all systems and components.
Incident Response: Coordinates responses to incidents detected through logs, ensuring timely action and compliance with regulations.
Monitoring Oversight: Regularly reviews monitoring mechanisms and reports to ensure the effectiveness of controls and compliance 
with internal standards.
The CISO plays a critical role in maintaining the integrity and security of the company's audit and monitoring practices.
2.2 Chief Information Officer (CIO)
The CIO is responsible for ensuring that technical infrastructure and systems meet the requirements outlined in the policy.
Infrastructure Alignment: Ensures that systems, network components, and applications support audit logging and monitoring 
requirements.
Log Protection: Works to safeguard logs by implementing access controls and ensuring proper backup and storage mechanisms.
System Management: Ensures all critical security control systems, such as IDS/IPS and network security controls, are properly 
monitored.
The following roles and responsibilities are to be developed and subsequently assigned to authorized personnel within the company 
regarding implementation of this document.
Groups and individuals definitions are given according to the Information Security Organization Policy .

The CIO ensures that the company's systems comply with the logging and monitoring requirements.
2.3 Responsible for Information Security (RIS)
The RIS manages day-to-day information security practices and ensures logging and monitoring are effectively implemented and 
maintained.
Daily Monitoring: Oversees routine monitoring activities, including log review and anomaly detection.
Incident Handling: Coordinates with the CISO and CIO during security incidents, ensuring that logs are analyzed, and proper 
responses are initiated.
Reporting: Generates reports based on logs and monitoring data to ensure compliance and highlight areas needing improvement.
The RIS ensures that logging and monitoring tasks are consistently carried out to maintain a secure environment.
2.4 System Administrators
System Administrators are responsible for implementing the logging mechanisms on systems and ensuring proper retention and protection.
Log Management: Sets up, configures, and maintains logging mechanisms across all critical systems.
Log Review: Ensures logs are reviewed regularly and securely backed up to central repositories.
Change Detection: Implements change-detection mechanisms to prevent unauthorized modifications to logs.
System Administrators ensure the operational integrity of the logging and monitoring systems.
2.5 Employees and Contractors
All employees and contractors are responsible for adhering to the logging and monitoring policies as outlined.
Incident Reporting: Report any incidents or suspicious activities observed in the logs.
Policy Compliance: Follow the procedures for handling sensitive data and logs as described in the policy.
Security Awareness: Participate in security awareness training related to logging and monitoring practices.
Employees and contractors play an important role in maintaining the integrity and security of the company's logging system by complying 
with the policy.
3 Policy
3.1 Event Logs
All systems at the company that access or handle sensitive information, accept network connections, manage access control (authentication 
and authorization), or impact the security of the environment (e.g., anti-malware utilities, firewalls) must record and retain audit logs. These 
logs must provide sufficient detail to answer the following questions:
What activity was performed?
Who performed the activity?
Where, when, and how was it performed (including the tools used)?
What was the status, outcome, or result of the activity?
By ensuring that logs capture this information, the company enhances its ability to monitor, review, and respond to security events, ensuring 
the integrity and security of its systems.
3.2 Logged Activities
Log records must be created for the following activities:

Sensitive Information Access:
Attempts to create, read, update, or delete sensitive information, including confidential authentication data such as passwords.
Network Connections:
Initiating or accepting a network connection.
User Authentication and Authorization:
User login and logout, as well as any changes to access rights.
Invalid Logical Access Attempts:
All unauthorized or failed logical access attempts.
Administrative Actions:
All actions performed by individuals with administrative or elevated privileges.
Attempts to grant, modify, or revoke access rights (e.g., adding a new user or group, changing user privilege levels, modifying file or 
database permissions).
Changes to firewall rules, user privileges, and database object permissions.
Modifications of administrative access, including user password changes and elevation of privileges.
Audit Log Access:
All access to audit logs, including actions such as starting, stopping, or pausing audit logs.
System-Level Changes:
Creation and deletion of system-level objects.
Changes in system, network, or services configuration, including the installation of software patches, updates, or other installed 
software modifications.
System Events:
Application and process events, such as startup, shutdown, or restart.
Application process failure, abnormal termination, or resource exhaustion (e.g., CPU, memory, network bandwidth, disk space).
Failures of critical services (e.g., DHCP, DNS), hardware faults, or hardware malfunctions.
Detection of Suspicious/Malicious Activity:
Detection and logging of potential security threats, including alerts from intrusion detection systems (IDS), intrusion prevention 
systems (IPS), web application firewalls, anti-malware systems, or anti-spyware tools.
By capturing these logged activities, the company ensures full visibility into system operations and enhances the ability to respond to 
potential security incidents or system malfunctions.
3.3 Log Elements
Each log must identify or contain the following elements to ensure thorough audit trails and log correlation where feasible (content may 
depend on system):
Type of Action      The specific action performed, such as authorize, create, read, update, delete, or network connection 
initiation. Includes whether the action was successful or failed. 
Subsystem           The process or transaction name responsible for performing the action. Examples include a system 
service or application transaction. 
Identifiers         Identifying information for the subject requesting the action, such as user name, computer name, IP 
address, MAC address. These identifiers should be standardized for easy correlation. 
Object of Action    Identifies what the action was performed on, such as file names accessed, records from a database, or 
specific network resources affected. 
ElementDescription

This structured approach ensures that logs provide comprehensive visibility into system activities, enabling effective monitoring, auditing, 
and security investigations.
3.4 Clock Synchronization
To ensure the accuracy of system logs, all system clocks must be synchronized using time-synchronization technology. The following 
requirements are mandatory for maintaining the integrity and consistency of audit logs:
Time Source: Logs must rely on accurate time sources, either International Atomic Time (TAI) or Coordinated Universal Time 
(UTC), to ensure uniformity across systems.
Network Time Protocol (NTP): All servers and critical infrastructure must use NTP to synchronize their clocks with a central time server. 
This ensures that the timestamps in audit logs are consistent across the environment.
Time Synchronization Settings:
Access Control: Time synchronization settings will be restricted to authorized personnel only. Changes to the time settings must be 
limited to those with a business need and appropriate permissions.
Logging Changes: Any modification to time settings on critical systems must be logged, including details of the personnel making 
the change and the reason for it.
Monitoring: System logs must be continuously monitored to ensure that no unauthorized or unintended changes to the time settings 
occur. Any detected discrepancies will be flagged and reviewed.
Auditing and Review: Regular reviews of time synchronization settings and logs will be conducted to detect any drift or misalignment in 
time stamps, ensuring the accuracy of all logged events.
This synchronization mechanism helps ensure that all log entries are recorded with accurate and consistent timestamps, which is essential 
for auditing, investigations, and compliance reporting.
3.5 Protection of Audit Logs
To ensure the integrity and security of audit logs, the following controls will be implemented to safeguard logs from tampering by individuals 
with elevated access or unauthorized users:
Access Control:
Restricted Access: Read access to audit logs will be strictly limited to personnel with a job-related need. Only authorized 
individuals responsible for monitoring or auditing system activity will be granted this access.
Administrator Restrictions: System administrators will be restricted from erasing, deactivating, or modifying logs of their own 
activities if possible. This ensures transparency and accountability for administrative actions.
Backup:
Centralized Backup: All audit log files, including those related to external-facing technologies, will be backed up to a secure, 
centralized internal log server or other secure media. These backups will be stored outside the direct control of system 
administrators to prevent manipulation.
Redundancy and Availability: Logs must be backed up on a regular basis, with redundancy measures in place to ensure log 
availability during recovery from failures or security incidents.
Before/After Values When applicable and feasible, records the before and after values of data elements that are updated as 
part of the action. 
Date and Time       The exact date and time the action was performed, including relevant time-zone information. For 
consistency, logs should use Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) when possible. 
Access Control Outcome Whether the action was allowed or denied by the system's access control mechanisms. 
Access Control Reason  In the event the action is denied, logs should contain descriptions or reason codes explaining why it 
was blocked. 

File Integrity Monitoring:
Change Detection: A file integrity monitoring (FIM) or change-detection mechanism will be employed to monitor and protect audit 
logs (where feasible based on system criticality, design and requirements). Any unauthorized or unexpected changes to the logs must 
generate real-time alerts.
Continuous Monitoring: All log data will be subjected to continuous monitoring, with alerts configured to detect suspicious or 
malicious activities targeting audit logs.
Review and Accountability:
Periodic Reviews: Logs related to privileged user activities, including system administrators and operators, will be reviewed 
regularly to ensure compliance with security policies and detect any misuse or unauthorized actions.
Accountability: All activities carried out by privileged users (e.g., system administrators) will be logged. These logs will be reviewed 
by security personnel and subjected to routine audits to maintain accountability.
Privileged Operations Logging:
Delegated Operations: In instances where privileged operations have been delegated to the company by third parties or customers, 
the performance of these operations will be logged and safeguarded. This ensures that all privileged actions are traceable and can 
be audited when necessary.
By implementing these protections, the integrity and availability of audit logs are maintained, ensuring they provide reliable evidence for 
audits, investigations, and security monitoring.
3.6 Monitoring
Failures in critical security control systems must be detected, alerted, and resolved promptly to maintain the integrity of the company's 
infrastructure. The systems that must be monitored include:
Network Security Controls: 
Intrusion Detection/Prevention Systems (IDS/IPS): Monitors network traffic for suspicious activities and responds to threats.
Firewalls: Ensures unauthorized network traffic is blocked, with real-time monitoring of firewall rule changes and suspicious 
connection attempts.
Access Controls: 
Physical Access Controls: Monitoring systems that track and alert on unauthorized physical access to sensitive areas such as data 
centers (not applicable for cloud environment, maintained by cloud provider).
Logical Access Controls: Ensuring that login attempts, failed logins, privilege escalations, and other access control mechanisms 
are actively monitored and alerting for unauthorized attempts.
Audit Logs: 
Automated Monitoring: Continuous monitoring of audit logs to detect anomalies, security breaches, and policy violations.
Periodic Reviews: Manual review of logs by authorized personnel to ensure adherence to company security policies and standards.
Change Detection Mechanisms: 
File Integrity Monitoring: Tracks and alerts on unauthorized changes to critical system files, configurations, and security settings.
System Configuration Monitoring: Detects any unsanctioned system changes, such as unauthorized software installations or 
misconfigurations.
Anti-malware Solutions: 
Threat Detection: Continuous monitoring for malware infections, suspicious activity, and potential threats across systems, with 
automatic alerts and incident reporting.
Failures identified within any of these critical control systems must be addressed promptly in accordance with the incident response 
policy. Actions include:
Restoring Security Functions:
Security functions must be immediately restored to minimize downtime and prevent further damage or compromise.
Documenting the Failure:

Duration: Accurately recording the start and end times of the security failure.
Cause Identification: Investigating the root cause of the failure and documenting it comprehensively.
Addressing Security Issues:
Impact Assessment: Identifying and addressing any security risks or vulnerabilities exposed by the failure.
Remediation: Implementing immediate fixes to resolve the issues, whether it is through patching, reconfiguring, or updating systems.
Evaluating Future Risk:
Preventative Actions: Implementing controls or improvements to prevent the reoccurrence of the failure.
Resuming Monitoring: Ensuring that the affected systems and controls are returned to full monitoring status to continue 
safeguarding against future incidents.
Incident Reporting:
Security incidents resulting from control failures must be logged, reported, and shared with relevant stakeholders, including IT and 
security teams, ensuring transparency and prompt action.
By enforcing continuous monitoring and establishing robust incident response mechanisms, the company ensures that failures in security 
controls are detected and addressed efficiently to minimize the impact on its operations and data security.

1 Purpose and Scope
1.1 Purpose
The Network Security Policy (further referred to as "the policy") outlines the company's approach to securing network infrastructure, 
protecting sensitive data, and ensuring the availability, integrity, and confidentiality of IT systems at Squirro AG (further referred to as "the 
company"). This policy defines network security controls, configurations, and responsibilities required to safeguard company assets and 
prevent unauthorized access, threats, and vulnerabilities.
1.2 Scope
The policy applies to:
All company personnel, contractors, and third-party providers interacting with company networks.
All network systems and assets, including physical and virtual servers, firewalls, routers, applications, and cloud infrastructure.
Any external connections or systems that have access to company data or networks.
All tools and utilities used to monitor, manage, or secure network operations within the company's IT environment.
1.3 Definitions
Firewall: A network security control that controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on an applied ruleset. A firewall 
establishes a barrier between a trusted, secure internal network or host and a network or host that is assumed not to be secure and 
trusted. Can be physical or virtual.
Host Based Firewalls: Firewalls designed to protect an individual system regardless of the network that the system is connected to. 
Host-based firewalls are typically provided as an integral component of the host's Operating System (OS) or as a third-party software 
add-on.
Network Perimeter Firewalls: Firewalls located at the boundary between the internal network and external networks such as the 
Internet. Network perimeter firewalls are purpose built enterprise grade devices (appliances).
Network Security Control: Network policy enforcement points that control network traffic between two or more logical or physical 
network segments (or subnets) based on predefined policies or rules. Include physical firewalls and other cloud access controls and 
software-defined networking technology.
Web Application Firewall: Controls incoming and outgoing network traffic at layer 7 of the OSI model. A web application firewall 
examines data content and allows or blocks traffic based on the content of the network connection.
Server: A computing device capable of accepting requests from a client and giving responses accordingly.
Systems: Servers, services, applications or network devices.
2 Roles and Responsibilities
2.1 Chief Information Security Officer (CISO)
The CISO is responsible for the overall implementation and enforcement of network security policies and ensuring compliance across the 
organization.
The following roles and responsibilities are to be developed and subsequently assigned to authorized personnel within the company 
regarding implementation of this document.
Groups and individuals definitions are given according to the Information Security Organization Policy .

Network Security Oversight: Oversees the deployment and monitoring of network security controls, ensuring they meet the company's 
security and business requirements.
Incident Response Coordination: Coordinates with security teams to respond to network incidents and breaches promptly.
Security Policy Review: Ensures periodic review and updates of network security policies to reflect evolving threats and compliance 
standards.
The CISO ensures that network security controls align with the company's strategic objectives and regulatory requirements.
2.2 Chief Information Officer (CIO)
The CIO oversees the infrastructure and ensures that security controls are aligned with business operations and objectives.
Infrastructure Management: Ensures that all systems, including cloud infrastructure and internal networks, are managed according to 
the security policy.
Network Architecture Reviews: Regularly reviews the network architecture to assess security gaps and recommend improvements.
Technology Implementation: Approves new network security technologies and ensures they are aligned with organizational goals.
The CIO guarantees that network security supports the scalability and functionality of IT operations.
2.3 Responsible for Information Security (RIS)
The RIS is tasked with monitoring and implementing security protocols across the company's IT infrastructure.
Security Controls Implementation: Manages the deployment of firewalls, intrusion detection systems (IDS/IPS), and web application 
firewalls (WAF) as per policy requirements.
Access Management: Ensures that all access control mechanisms are correctly configured and monitored.
Log and Audit Management: Oversees the review of system logs and security event data for suspicious activity.
The RIS is responsible for day-to-day monitoring and maintaining the integrity of the network.
2.4 Network Security Administrator
The Network Security Administrator is responsible for the technical management of firewalls, IDS/IPS, and other network security devices.
Firewall Management: Configures and maintains firewall rules to allow only authorized traffic based on business needs.
Intrusion Detection: Monitors IDS/IPS alerts, investigates suspicious activity, and ensures timely response to potential threats.
Security Patches: Applies necessary security patches to network devices and manages configurations to mitigate vulnerabilities.
Network Security Administrators ensure that network security controls are operational and effective in mitigating threats.
2.5 IT Support Staff
IT Support Staff assist in implementing security protocols, troubleshooting issues, and providing first-level response to network incidents.
Network Monitoring: Assists in monitoring network traffic for anomalies and security breaches.
Configuration Support: Helps in configuring network devices under the guidance of Network Security Administrators.
Incident Reporting: Reports any suspicious network activity or potential incidents to the RIS or CISO.
IT Support Staff help ensure network security policies are followed during daily operations.
3 Policy
The company subscribes to a layered defense or defense-in-depth approach to network security; network security controls are an essential 
layer of company's IT security infrastructure. This policy outlines key requirements for network security controls in scope and must be 
adhered to at all times.

3.1 Network Representations
A representation of network boundaries and data flows will be maintained and updated regularly.
Network Boundary Representation: A detailed network diagram showing the boundaries between trusted and untrusted networks will 
be documented and kept up to date through periodic reviews.
Data Flow Representation: All data flows between system components and across network segments will be documented and 
reviewed periodically, particularly after any changes to the environment.
All network diagrams and data flow representations will be used to monitor and manage network security effectively.
3.2 Network Security Controls
Network security controls will be deployed and maintained to protect systems and prevent unauthorized access.
Intrusion Protection: Network security controls will block harmful traffic and prevent suspicious anomalies and intrusions.
Traffic Restriction: Inbound and outbound network traffic will be limited to what is necessary based on business requirements. Default 
deny-all rules will be implemented to block unauthorized traffic.
Perimeter and Host-Based Security: Squirro's servers will be protected by network perimeter firewalls and host-based firewalls.
Trusted vs. Untrusted Networks: Security controls will be implemented between trusted and untrusted networks to prevent 
unauthorized traffic from crossing network boundaries.
Inbound Traffic Restrictions: Inbound traffic from untrusted networks will only communicate with authorized system components 
providing public services, while all other traffic will be denied.
Web Application Firewall: A web application firewall (WAF) must be deployed to protect web applications from external attacks where 
feasible.
These network security controls form part of a layered defense strategy to safeguard Squirro's IT systems.
3.3 Configuration Standards
Configuration standards for network security controls will be documented and adhered to for all devices and software components.
Documented Standards: Configuration standards for firewalls, routers, access control lists, and virtual networks will be documented.
Business Justification: All allowed services, protocols, and ports must be documented, approved, and justified by a business need.
Configuration File Security: Configuration files for network security controls will be secured against unauthorized access and kept 
consistent with active network configurations.
Proper documentation and security of configuration standards ensure consistent protection across the network.
3.4 Maintenance of Network Security Controls
Network security controls must be maintained regularly to ensure continued protection and compliance.
Change Management: All changes to network configurations and connections must be documented and approved following the Change 
Management Policy.
Annual Ruleset Review: Network security control rulesets will be reviewed at least annually to ensure they are up to date and effective.
Administrative Access Logging: All administrative access to firewall configurations must be logged and regularly monitored. Reviews 
of firewall and ruleset configurations must be performed on a regular basis.
Regular maintenance and review of network security controls ensure their effectiveness in protecting the environment.
3.5 Monitoring of Activity
Real-time monitoring of network activity will be implemented to detect potential security threats.

Intrusion Detection and Prevention: An IDS/IPS or equivalent system will be deployed to detect suspicious or anomalous traffic in real 
time. Alerts will be generated when potential intrusions are detected.
System Updates: All IDS/IPS engines, baselines, and signatures will be kept up to date to ensure accurate detection of security threats.
The monitoring of network activity provides early detection of threats, allowing for swift response and mitigation.

add-on.

Internet. Network perimeter firewalls are purpose built enterprise grade devices (appliances).
Network Security Control: Network policy enforcement points that control network traffic between two or more logical or physical 
network segments (or subnets) based on predefined policies or rules. Include physical firewalls and other cloud access controls and 
software-defined networking technology.
Web Application Firewall: Controls incoming and outgoing network traffic at layer 7 of the OSI model. A web application firewall 
examines data content and allows or blocks traffic based on the content of the network connection.
Server: A computing device capable of accepting requests from a client and giving responses accordingly.

Traffic Restriction: Inbound and outbound network traffic will be limited to what is necessary based on business requirements. Default 
deny-all rules will be implemented to block unauthorized traffic.

Trusted vs. Untrusted Networks: Security controls will be implemented between trusted and untrusted networks to prevent 
unauthorized traffic from crossing network boundaries.
Inbound Traffic Restrictions: Inbound traffic from untrusted networks will only communicate with authorized system components 
providing public services, while all other traffic will be denied.
Web Application Firewall: A web application firewall (WAF) must be deployed to protect web applications from external attacks where 
feasible.
These network security controls form part of a layered defense strategy to safeguard Squirro's IT systems.

Configuration standards for network security controls will be documented and adhered to for all devices and software components.
Documented Standards: Configuration standards for firewalls, routers, access control lists, and virtual networks will be documented.
Business Justification: All allowed services, protocols, and ports must be documented, approved, and justified by a business need.

consistent with active network configurations.

Network security controls must be maintained regularly to ensure continued protection and compliance.
Change Management: All changes to network configurations and connections must be documented and approved following the Change 
Management Policy.

Administrative Access Logging: All administrative access to firewall configurations must be logged and regularly monitored. Reviews 
of firewall and ruleset configurations must be performed on a regular basis.
Regular maintenance and review of network security controls ensure their effectiveness in protecting the environment.
